docs.text: I crushed them completely, and they could not rise; they fell beneath my feet.

docs.title: v.40
docs.text: You armed me with strength for battle; you made my adversaries bow at my feet.

docs.title: v.41
docs.text: You made my enemies turn their backs in flight, and I destroyed my foes.

docs.text: They cried for help, but there was no one to save them— to the LORD, but he did not answer.

docs.title: v.45

docs.title: v.46
docs.text: They all lose heart; they come trembling from their strongholds.

docs.title: v.47
docs.text: "The LORD lives! Praise be to my Rock! Exalted be God, the Rock, my Savior!

docs.text: He is the God who avenges me, who puts the nations under me,

docs.title: v.49
docs.text: who sets me free from my enemies. You exalted me above my foes; from violent men you rescued me.

docs.title: v.50
docs.text: Therefore I will praise you, O LORD, among the nations; I will sing praises to your name.

docs.title: v.51
docs.text: He gives his king great victories; he shows unfailing kindness to his anointed, to David and his descendants forever."

docs.title: v.1
docs.text: These are the last words of David: "The oracle of David son of Jesse, the oracle of the man exalted by the Most High, the man anointed by the God of Jacob, Israel's singer of songs :

docs.title: v.2
docs.text: "The Spirit of the LORD spoke through me; his word was on my tongue.

docs.title: v.3
docs.text:
The God of Israel spoke, the Rock of Israel said to me: 'When one rules over men in righteousness, when he rules in the fear of God,

The Lord chose David to embody the Deuteronomic ideal of kingship (Deut. 17:14–20). He was to promote righteousness and to fear the Lord, and in so doing to be an instrument of divine blessing for his people (vv. 3–4). At the same time, David could be confident in his covenantal relationship with the Lord, knowing that the divine promises had been formalized and secured (v. 5a). Thus David could expect to experience divine protection and blessing (v. 5b) and to see the demise of evil rebels (vv. 6–7). So, in short, the Davidic covenant demands that the chosen king promote God’s moral standard; it also guarantees that obedience will be rewarded.

docs.title: v.4
docs.text: he is like the light of morning at sunrise on a cloudless morning, like the brightness after rain that brings the grass from the earth.'

docs.title: v.5
docs.text:
"Is not my house right with God? Has he not made with me an everlasting covenant, arranged and secured in every part? Will he not bring to fruition my salvation and grant me my every desire?

This is the only place in the Old Testament where the Davidic covenant is specifically called “everlasting,” but its perpetual, irrevocable nature is stated elsewhere (2 Sam. 7:13, 16; Ps. 89:4, 28, 36–37). For fuller discussion of the nature of the Davidic covenant, see comments above on 2 Samuel 7.

docs.title: v.6

docs.title: v.7
docs.text: Whoever touches thorns uses a tool of iron or the shaft of a spear; they are burned up where they lie."

docs.title: v.9

docs.title: v.10
docs.text: but he stood his ground and struck down the Philistines till his hand grew tired and froze to the sword. The LORD brought about a great victory that day. The troops returned to Eleazar, but only to strip the dead.

docs.title: v.11
docs.text: Next to him was Shammah son of Agee the Hararite. When the Philistines banded together at a place where there was a field full of lentils, Israel's troops fled from them.

docs.text: But Shammah took his stand in the middle of the field. He defended it and struck the Philistines down, and the LORD brought about a great victory.

docs.title: v.13
docs.text: During harvest time, three of the thirty chief men came down to David at the cave of Adullam, while a band of Philistines was encamped in the Valley of Rephaim.

docs.title: v.14
docs.text: At that time David was in the stronghold, and the Philistine garrison was at Bethlehem.

docs.title: v.15
docs.text: David longed for water and said, "Oh, that someone would get me a drink of water from the well near the gate of Bethlehem!"

docs.title: v.16

docs.title: v.17
docs.text: "Far be it from me, O LORD, to do this!" he said. "Is it not the blood of men who went at the risk of their lives?" And David would not drink it. Such were the exploits of the three mighty men.

docs.title: v.18
docs.text: Abishai the brother of Joab son of Zeruiah was chief of the Three. He raised his spear against three hundred men, whom he killed, and so he became as famous as the Three.

docs.title: v.19
docs.text: Was he not held in greater honor than the Three? He became their commander, even though he was not included among them.

docs.title: v.20
docs.text: Benaiah son of Jehoiada was a valiant fighter from Kabzeel, who performed great exploits. He struck down two of Moab's best men. He also went down into a pit on a snowy day and killed a lion.

docs.text: And he struck down a huge Egyptian. Although the Egyptian had a spear in his hand, Benaiah went against him with a club. He snatched the spear from the Egyptian's hand and killed him with his own spear.

docs.title: v.1
docs.text: Again the anger of the LORD burned against Israel, and he incited David against them, saying, "Go and take a census of Israel and Judah."

docs.title: v.2
docs.text: So the king said to Joab and the army commanders with him, "Go throughout the tribes of Israel from Dan to Beersheba and enroll the fighting men, so that I may know how many there are."

docs.title: v.3
docs.text: But Joab replied to the king, "May the LORD your God multiply the troops a hundred times over, and may the eyes of my lord the king see it. But why does my lord the king want to do such a thing?"

docs.title: v.4
docs.text: The king's word, however, overruled Joab and the army commanders; so they left the presence of the king to enroll the fighting men of Israel.

docs.title: v.5
docs.text: After crossing the Jordan, they camped near Aroer, south of the town in the gorge, and then went through Gad and on to Jazer.

docs.title: v.6
docs.text: They went to Gilead and the region of Tahtim Hodshi, and on to Dan Jaan and around toward Sidon.

docs.title: v.7

docs.title: v.8

Throughout the ancient world it was believed that prophets not only proclaimed the message of deity but in the process unleashed the divine action. In Assyrian king Esarhaddon’s instructions to his vassals, he requires that they report any improper or negative statements made by anyone, specifically naming prophets, ecstatics and dream interpreters. It is no wonder, then, that a prophet negatively disposed toward a king had to be controlled lest he bring about all sorts of havoc. One can perhaps understand why a king would be inclined to imprison a prophet whose very words might incite insurrection or impose doom.

The occassion for the spiritual warfare was the restoration of the believing remnant of Israel to the Holy Land and their survival there as a commonwealth of the faithful, living in obedience to the Scriptures. Knowing that such a development could lead to the ultimate appearance of the Messiah, Satan and his hosts were determined to thwart the renewal of Israel and the deliverance of her people from destruction. The supreme effort to exterminate them altogether was to take place some fifty-five years later, in the reign of Ashasuerus (Xerxes), when Haman secured his consent to obliterate the entire Jewish race (see the book of Esther). The conflict between Michael and the "prince of Persia" (10:13) may have had some bearing on the event, and Michael's victory may have paved the way for Queen Esther to thwart this genocide. The second major effort of Satan was to take place under Antiochus Epiphanes, who sought to obliterate the Jewish faith by forbidding its practice on pain of death. The momentous events of 167-164 B.C. may well have been profoundly affected by this supernatural warfare between heaven and hell.

docs.title: v.28
docs.text:
“This is the end of the matter. I, Daniel, was deeply troubled by my thoughts, and my face turned pale, but I kept the matter to myself.”

I communicated to no one the cause of my deep and anxious thoughts. He hid the whole subject in his own mind, until he thought proper to make this record of what he had seen and heard. Perhaps there was no one to whom he could communicate the matter who would credit it; perhaps there was no one at court who would sympathize with him; perhaps he thought that it might savor of vanity if it were known; perhaps he felt that as no one could throw any new light on the subject, there would be no use in making it a subject of conversation; perhaps he felt so overpowered that he could not readily converse on it.

docs.title: v.1
docs.text: In the third year of King Belshazzar's reign, I, Daniel, had a vision, after the one that had already appeared to me.

docs.title: v.2
docs.text: In my vision I saw myself in the citadel of Susa in the province of Elam; in the vision I was beside the Ulai Canal.

docs.title: v.3
docs.text: I looked up, and there before me was a ram with two horns, standing beside the canal, and the horns were long. One of the horns was longer than the other but grew up later.

docs.title: v.4
docs.text: I watched the ram as he charged toward the west and the north and the south. No animal could stand against him, and none could rescue from his power. He did as he pleased and became great.

docs.title: v.5
docs.text:
As I was thinking about this, suddenly a goat with a prominent horn between its eyes came from the west, crossing the whole earth without touching the ground.

The completeness of Alexander's victories is fittingly prefigured by this crushing attack on the ram. Alexander's conquest of the entire Near and Middle East within three years stands unique in military history and is appropriately portrayed by the lightning speed of this one-horned goat.

docs.title: v.6
docs.text: He came toward the two-horned ram I had seen standing beside the canal and charged at him in great rage.

docs.title: v.7
docs.text: I saw him attack the ram furiously, striking the ram and shattering his two horns. The ram was powerless to stand against him; the goat knocked him to the ground and trampled on him, and none could rescue the ram from his power.

docs.title: v.8
docs.text:
The goat became very great, but at the height of its power the large horn was broken off, and in its place four prominent horns grew up toward the four winds of heaven.

"The goat became very great" suggests Alexander's thrust beyond the borders of the empire he had conquered even into Afghanistan and Indus Valley (327 B.C.). Or it may refer to the growth in arrogance that led him to assume the pretensions to divinity that distressed his Macedonian troops, who finally mutinied.

Yet, as v.8 predicts, "at the height of his [the goat's] power his large horn was broken off." Alexander died of a sudden fever brought on by dissipation (though it was rumored that he was actually poisoned by Cassander, the son of Antipater, viceroy of Macedonia) at Babylon in 323, at the age of thirty-three.

docs.title: v.9
docs.text:
Out of one of them came another horn, which started small but grew in power to the south and to the east and toward the Beautiful Land.

This evidently refers to the career of Antiochus IV Epiphanes ("the Manifest/Conspicuous One"), who usurped the Seleucid throne from his nephew (son of his older brother, Seleucus IV) and succeeded in invading Egypt 170-169 B.C.

docs.title: v.10

docs.title: v.23-24
docs.text:
"In the latter part of their reign, when rebels have become completely wicked, a stern-faced king, a master of intrigue, will arise. 24He will become very strong, but not by his own power. He will cause astounding devastation and will succeed in whatever he does. He will destroy the mighty men and the holy people.

This passage depicts the rise of Antiochus Epiphanes, described as a "stern-faced king, a master of intrigue" (lit, "a master at understanding hidden things"), who will at first enjoy much success. He will crush "mighty men" (presumably nobles and rival claimants to the throne) and also "the holy people" (i.e., the believing Jews).

docs.title: v.25
docs.text:
He will cause deceit to prosper, and he will consider himself superior. When they feel secure, he will destroy many and take his stand against the Prince of princes. Yet he will be destroyed, but not by human power.

As a condign penalty for having taken "his stand against the Prince of princes" (the Lord God Almighty), Antiochus would be removed from the scene. He was. After making an unsuccessful attempt to pillage Nanaea, a wealthy temple in Elymais, he died of a sudden malady. Ancient sources have somewhat diverse accounts of Antiochus's fatal illness. The author of 1Mc 6:4, 8-16 says that Antiochus withdrew to Babylon after his repulse at Elymais, that he became deathly ill after hearing of the victories of Judas Maccabaeus, and that he died many days later. But 2Mc 9:1-28 states that Antiochus had attempted to raid a temple in Persepolis (rather than Elymais), and that it was at Ecbatana that he heard the disturbing news of the Maccabean victories. Then, as he was uttering dire threats of reprisal against them, he was seized with severe abdominal pains that never left him; and thus he fell out of the chariot in which he was riding. Finally, as a result of his severe injuries from the fall and the attack of worms on his bowels, accompanied by a revolting stench, he finally died with vain petitions on his lips, imploring the God of Israel to spare his life. The various accounts agree in stating that the tyrant met his end by a nonhuman agency. The question of Antiochus's death is of special importance in 11:45.

So I turned to the Lord God and pleaded with him in prayer and petition, in fasting, and in sackcloth and ashes.

The impact of the revelation of the gap between the prophetic promises and the current crises moves the heart of the renewed man to his knees and humility. Prophecy is revelation of the need God intends to fulfill. When we align with it, the fulfillment of such prophecy becomes our need since it is God's will.

Sin has effects beyond personal conviction. It's so disgusting that it infects leaders and entire generations with shame and concealment of seeing God rightly.

docs.text:
The Lord our God is merciful and forgiving, even though we have rebelled against him;

We can only appeal to the Judge whom we have rebelled against for forgiveness. If we have sinned against God, it is only God who can forgive such sins.

docs.title: v.13
docs.text:
Just as it is written in the Law of Moses, all this disaster has come on us, yet we have not sought the favor of the Lord our God by turning from our sins and giving attention to your truth.

Here it means, that, as a people, they had failed, when they had sinned, to call upon God for pardon; to confess their sins; to implore his mercy; to deprecate his wrath. It would have been easy to turn aside his threatened judgments if they had been penitent, and had sought his mercy, but they had not done it. What is here said of them can and will be said of all sinners when the Divine judgment comes upon them.

His judgements are not good or bad. They are right.

“Now, our God, hear the prayers and petitions of your servant. For your sake, Lord, look with favor on your desolate sanctuary.

The glory of God is at stake.

docs.title: Overview:
docs.text:
deuteronomy → "second law." Written to the second generation (children of the Exodus who wandered for 40 years).

Theme: Remembrance Key Scripture: 10:12-13

Chapters 1-4: Moses tells the story of the deliverance from Egypt and how Israel came to be where they are now. Chapters 4-28: Moses tells the moral of the story. Reviews the law that was passed down and its three aspects: moral, ceremonial, and civil. Chapters 29-30: Moses prophesies the future of Israel. Chapters 31-34: Moses gives last words and passes leadership to Joshua.

Purposes: 1. To show that Israel needed to be reminded. 1. People need to be reminded more than they need to be instructed. - Samuel Johnson 2. To show Israel's preparation for entering, conquering, and possessing. 3. To show God's faithfulness to the generations. 1. God's vision is beyond one generation.

Messages: 1. Love is the key to the kingdom of God. 1. Jesus said the greatest commandment is to love God with all their heart, mind, soul, and strength. 2. The Word of God enables us to know what His will is. 1. His will is in His word. As Israel understands His word, they will understand His will.

docs.text: if only you fully obey the LORD your God and are careful to follow all these commands I am giving you today.

docs.title: v.6
docs.text: For the LORD your God will bless you as he has promised, and you will lend to many nations but will borrow from none. You will rule over many nations but none will rule over you.

docs.title: v.7
docs.text: If there is a poor man among your brothers in any of the towns of the land that the LORD your God is giving you, do not be hardhearted or tightfisted toward your poor brother.

docs.title: v.8
docs.text: Rather be openhanded and freely lend him whatever he needs.

docs.title: v.9
docs.text: Be careful not to harbor this wicked thought: "The seventh year, the year for canceling debts, is near," so that you do not show ill will toward your needy brother and give him nothing. He may then appeal to the LORD against you, and you will be found guilty of sin.

docs.title: v.10
docs.text: Give generously to him and do so without a grudging heart; then because of this the LORD your God will bless you in all your work and in everything you put your hand to.

docs.title: v.11
docs.text: There will always be poor people in the land. Therefore I command you to be openhanded toward your brothers and toward the poor and needy in your land.

docs.title: v.12
docs.text: If a fellow Hebrew, a man or a woman, sells himself to you and serves you six years, in the seventh year you must let him go free.

docs.title: v.13
docs.text: And when you release him, do not send him away empty-handed.

docs.title: v.14
docs.text: Supply him liberally from your flock, your threshing floor and your winepress. Give to him as the LORD your God has blessed you.

docs.title: v.15
docs.text: Remember that you were slaves in Egypt and the LORD your God redeemed you. That is why I give you this command today.

docs.title: v.16
docs.text: But if your servant says to you, "I do not want to leave you," because he loves you and your family and is well off with you,

docs.title: v.17
docs.text: then take an awl and push it through his ear lobe into the door, and he will become your servant for life. Do the same for your maidservant.

docs.title: v.18
docs.text: Do not consider it a hardship to set your servant free, because his service to you these six years has been worth twice as much as that of a hired hand. And the LORD your God will bless you in everything you do.

docs.title: v.19
docs.text: Set apart for the LORD your God every firstborn male of your herds and flocks. Do not put the firstborn of your oxen to work, and do not shear the firstborn of your sheep.

docs.title: v.20
docs.text: Each year you and your family are to eat them in the presence of the LORD your God at the place he will choose.

docs.title: v.21
docs.text: If an animal has a defect, is lame or blind, or has any serious flaw, you must not sacrifice it to the LORD your God.

docs.title: v.22
docs.text: You are to eat it in your own towns. Both the ceremonially unclean and the clean may eat it, as if it were gazelle or deer.

docs.title: v.23
docs.text: But you must not eat the blood; pour it out on the ground like water.

docs.title: v.6
docs.text: On the testimony of two or three witnesses a man shall be put to death, but no one shall be put to death on the testimony of only one witness.

docs.title: v.7
docs.text: The hands of the witnesses must be the first in putting him to death, and then the hands of all the people. You must purge the evil from among you.

docs.title: v.12-13
docs.text: The man who shows contempt for the judge or for the priest who stands ministering there to the LORD your God must be put to death. You must purge the evil from Israel. 13All the people will hear and be afraid, and will not be contemptuous again.

docs.title: v.16-17
docs.text: The king, moreover, must not acquire great numbers of horses for himself or make the people return to Egypt to get more of them, for the LORD has told you, "You are not to go back that way again." 17He must not take many wives, or his heart will be led astray. He must not accumulate large amounts of silver and gold.

docs.title: v.18-20
docs.text: When he takes the throne of his kingdom, he is to write for himself on a scroll a copy of this law, taken from that of the priests, who are Levites. 19It is to be with him, and he is to read it all the days of his life so that he may learn to revere the LORD his God and follow carefully all the words of this law and these decrees 20and not consider himself better than his brothers and turn from the law to the right or to the left. Then he and his descendants will reign a long time over his kingdom in Israel.

docs.title: v.15
docs.text: One witness is not enough to convict a man accused of any crime or offense he may have committed. A matter must be established by the testimony of two or three witnesses.

docs.title: v.1
docs.text: Then we turned back and set out toward the desert along the route to the Red Sea, as the LORD had directed me. For a long time we made our way around the hill country of Seir.

docs.title: v.2
docs.text: Then the LORD said to me,

docs.title: v.3
docs.text: "You have made your way around this hill country long enough; now turn north.

docs.title: v.4
docs.text: Give the people these orders: 'You are about to pass through the territory of your brothers the descendants of Esau, who live in Seir. They will be afraid of you, but be very careful.

docs.title: v.5
docs.text: Do not provoke them to war, for I will not give you any of their land, not even enough to put your foot on. I have given Esau the hill country of Seir as his own.

docs.title: v.6
docs.text: You are to pay them in silver for the food you eat and the water you drink.'"

docs.title: v.7
docs.text:
The LORD your God has blessed you in all the work of your hands. He has watched over your journey through this vast desert. These forty years the LORD your God has been with you, and you have not lacked anything.

Spurgeon sermon

docs.title: v.8
docs.text: So we went on past our brothers the descendants of Esau, who live in Seir. We turned from the Arabah road, which comes up from Elath and Ezion Geber, and traveled along the desert road of Moab.

docs.title: v.9
docs.text: Then the LORD said to me, "Do not harass the Moabites or provoke them to war, for I will not give you any part of their land. I have given Ar to the descendants of Lot as a possession."

docs.title: v.10
docs.text: (The Emites used to live there—a people strong and numerous, and as tall as the Anakites.

docs.title: v.11
docs.text: Like the Anakites, they too were considered Rephaites, but the Moabites called them Emites.

docs.title: v.12
docs.text: Horites used to live in Seir, but the descendants of Esau drove them out. They destroyed the Horites from before them and settled in their place, just as Israel did in the land the LORD gave them as their possession.)

docs.title: v.13
docs.text: And the LORD said, "Now get up and cross the Zered Valley." So we crossed the valley.

docs.title: v.14
docs.text: Thirty-eight years passed from the time we left Kadesh Barnea until we crossed the Zered Valley. By then, that entire generation of fighting men had perished from the camp, as the LORD had sworn to them.

docs.title: v.15
docs.text: The LORD's hand was against them until he had completely eliminated them from the camp.

docs.title: v.16
docs.text: Now when the last of these fighting men among the people had died,

docs.title: v.17
docs.text: the LORD said to me,

docs.title: v.18
docs.text: "Today you are to pass by the region of Moab at Ar.

docs.title: v.19
docs.text: When you come to the Ammonites, do not harass them or provoke them to war, for I will not give you possession of any land belonging to the Ammonites. I have given it as a possession to the descendants of Lot."

docs.title: v.20
docs.text: (That too was considered a land of the Rephaites, who used to live there; but the Ammonites called them Zamzummites.

docs.title: v.21
docs.text: They were a people strong and numerous, and as tall as the Anakites. The LORD destroyed them from before the Ammonites, who drove them out and settled in their place.

docs.title: v.22
docs.text: The LORD had done the same for the descendants of Esau, who lived in Seir, when he destroyed the Horites from before them. They drove them out and have lived in their place to this day.

docs.title: v.23
docs.text: And as for the Avvites who lived in villages as far as Gaza, the Caphtorites coming out from Caphtor destroyed them and settled in their place.)

docs.title: v.24
docs.text: "Set out now and cross the Arnon Gorge. See, I have given into your hand Sihon the Amorite, king of Heshbon, and his country. Begin to take possession of it and engage him in battle.

docs.title: v.25
docs.text: This very day I will begin to put the terror and fear of you on all the nations under heaven. They will hear reports of you and will tremble and be in anguish because of you."

docs.title: v.26
docs.text: From the desert of Kedemoth I sent messengers to Sihon king of Heshbon offering peace and saying,

docs.title: v.27
docs.text: "Let us pass through your country. We will stay on the main road; we will not turn aside to the right or to the left.

docs.title: v.28
docs.text: Sell us food to eat and water to drink for their price in silver. Only let us pass through on foot—

docs.title: v.29
docs.text: as the descendants of Esau, who live in Seir, and the Moabites, who live in Ar, did for us—until we cross the Jordan into the land the LORD our God is giving us."

docs.title: v.30
docs.text: But Sihon king of Heshbon refused to let us pass through. For the LORD your God had made his spirit stubborn and his heart obstinate in order to give him into your hands, as he has now done.

docs.title: v.31
docs.text: The LORD said to me, "See, I have begun to deliver Sihon and his country over to you. Now begin to conquer and possess his land."

docs.title: v.32
docs.text: When Sihon and all his army came out to meet us in battle at Jahaz,

docs.title: v.33
docs.text: the LORD our God delivered him over to us and we struck him down, together with his sons and his whole army.

docs.title: v.34
docs.text: At that time we took all his towns and completely destroyed them—men, women and children. We left no survivors.

docs.title: v.35
docs.text: But the livestock and the plunder from the towns we had captured we carried off for ourselves.

docs.title: v.36
docs.text: From Aroer on the rim of the Arnon Gorge, and from the town in the gorge, even as far as Gilead, not one town was too strong for us. The LORD our God gave us all of them.

docs.title: v.37
docs.text: But in accordance with the command of the LORD our God, you did not encroach on any of the land of the Ammonites, neither the land along the course of the Jabbok nor that around the towns in the hills.

docs.title: v.1
docs.text: If a man is found slain, lying in a field in the land the LORD your God is giving you to possess, and it is not known who killed him,

docs.title: v.2
docs.text: your elders and judges shall go out and measure the distance from the body to the neighboring towns.

docs.title: v.3
docs.text: Then the elders of the town nearest the body shall take a heifer that has never been worked and has never worn a yoke

docs.title: v.4
docs.text: and lead her down to a valley that has not been plowed or planted and where there is a flowing stream. There in the valley they are to break the heifer's neck.

docs.title: v.5
docs.text: The priests, the sons of Levi, shall step forward, for the LORD your God has chosen them to minister and to pronounce blessings in the name of the LORD and to decide all cases of dispute and assault.

docs.title: v.6
docs.text: Then all the elders of the town nearest the body shall wash their hands over the heifer whose neck was broken in the valley,

docs.title: v.7
docs.text: and they shall declare: "Our hands did not shed this blood, nor did our eyes see it done.

docs.title: v.8
docs.text: Accept this atonement for your people Israel, whom you have redeemed, O LORD, and do not hold your people guilty of the blood of an innocent man." And the bloodshed will be atoned for.

docs.title: v.9
docs.text: So you will purge from yourselves the guilt of shedding innocent blood, since you have done what is right in the eyes of the LORD.

docs.title: v.10
docs.text: When you go to war against your enemies and the LORD your God delivers them into your hands and you take captives,

docs.title: v.11
docs.text: if you notice among the captives a beautiful woman and are attracted to her, you may take her as your wife.

docs.title: v.12
docs.text: Bring her into your home and have her shave her head, trim her nails

docs.title: v.13
docs.text: and put aside the clothes she was wearing when captured. After she has lived in your house and mourned her father and mother for a full month, then you may go to her and be her husband and she shall be your wife.

docs.title: v.14
docs.text: If you are not pleased with her, let her go wherever she wishes. You must not sell her or treat her as a slave, since you have dishonored her.

docs.title: v.15-17
docs.text:
If a man has two wives, and he loves one but not the other, and both bear him sons but the firstborn is the son of the wife he does not love, 16when he wills his property to his sons, he must not give the rights of the firstborn to the son of the wife he loves in preference to his actual firstborn, the son of the wife he does not love. 17He must acknowledge the son of his unloved wife as the firstborn by giving him a double share of all he has. That son is the first sign of his father's strength. The right of the firstborn belongs to him.

Likewise, Deuteronomy 21:15-17 legislates the rights of the firstborn, regardless of whether that child is the son of the preferred wife or of the wife who is not loved. To contend, as some do, that legislation on rights within polygamy tacitly condones polygamy makes about as much sense as saying that Deuteronomy 23:18 approves of harlotry since it prohibits bringing the wages earned by harlotry into the house of the Lord for any vow!

docs.title: hardsayingsofthebible
docs.text: See also Exodus 21:10-11, Leviticus 18:18, and 2 Samuel 12:8.

docs.title: v.18
docs.text: If a man has a stubborn and rebellious son who does not obey his father and mother and will not listen to them when they discipline him,

docs.title: v.19
docs.text: his father and mother shall take hold of him and bring him to the elders at the gate of his town.

docs.title: v.20
docs.text: They shall say to the elders, "This son of ours is stubborn and rebellious. He will not obey us. He is a profligate and a drunkard."

docs.title: v.21
docs.text: Then all the men of his town shall stone him to death. You must purge the evil from among you. All Israel will hear of it and be afraid.

docs.title: v.22
docs.text: If a man guilty of a capital offense is put to death and his body is hung on a tree,

docs.title: v.23
docs.text: you must not leave his body on the tree overnight. Be sure to bury him that same day, because anyone who is hung on a tree is under God's curse. You must not desecrate the land the LORD your God is giving you as an inheritance.

docs.title: v.10
docs.text: Do not plow with an ox and a donkey yoked together.

docs.title: v.1
docs.text: No one who has been emasculated by crushing or cutting may enter the assembly of the LORD.

docs.title: v.2
docs.text: No one born of a forbidden marriage nor any of his descendants may enter the assembly of the LORD, even down to the tenth generation.

docs.title: v.3
docs.text: No Ammonite or Moabite or any of his descendants may enter the assembly of the LORD, even down to the tenth generation.

docs.title: v.4
docs.text: For they did not come to meet you with bread and water on your way when you came out of Egypt, and they hired Balaam son of Beor from Pethor in Aram Naharaim to pronounce a curse on you.

docs.title: v.5
docs.text: However, the LORD your God would not listen to Balaam but turned the curse into a blessing for you, because the LORD your God loves you.

docs.title: v.6
docs.text: Do not seek a treaty of friendship with them as long as you live.

docs.title: v.7
docs.text: Do not abhor an Edomite, for he is your brother. Do not abhor an Egyptian, because you lived as an alien in his country.

docs.title: v.8
docs.text: The third generation of children born to them may enter the assembly of the LORD.

docs.title: v.9
docs.text: When you are encamped against your enemies, keep away from everything impure.

docs.title: v.10
docs.text: If one of your men is unclean because of a nocturnal emission, he is to go outside the camp and stay there.

docs.title: v.11
docs.text: But as evening approaches he is to wash himself, and at sunset he may return to the camp.

docs.title: v.12
docs.text: Designate a place outside the camp where you can go to relieve yourself.

docs.title: v.13
docs.text: As part of your equipment have something to dig with, and when you relieve yourself, dig a hole and cover up your excrement.

docs.title: v.14
docs.text: For the LORD your God moves about in your camp to protect you and to deliver your enemies to you. Your camp must be holy, so that he will not see among you anything indecent and turn away from you.

docs.title: v.15
docs.text: If a slave has taken refuge with you, do not hand him over to his master.

docs.title: v.16
docs.text: Let him live among you wherever he likes and in whatever town he chooses. Do not oppress him.

docs.title: v.17
docs.text: No Israelite man or woman is to become a shrine prostitute.

docs.title: v.18
docs.text: You must not bring the earnings of a female prostitute or of a male prostitute into the house of the LORD your God to pay any vow, because the LORD your God detests them both.

docs.title: v.19
docs.text: Do not charge your brother interest, whether on money or food or anything else that may earn interest.

docs.title: v.20
docs.text: You may charge a foreigner interest, but not a brother Israelite, so that the LORD your God may bless you in everything you put your hand to in the land you are entering to possess.

docs.title: v.21
docs.text: If you make a vow to the LORD your God, do not be slow to pay it, for the LORD your God will certainly demand it of you and you will be guilty of sin.

docs.title: v.22
docs.text: But if you refrain from making a vow, you will not be guilty.

docs.title: v.23
docs.text: Whatever your lips utter you must be sure to do, because you made your vow freely to the LORD your God with your own mouth.

docs.title: v.24
docs.text: If you enter your neighbor's vineyard, you may eat all the grapes you want, but do not put any in your basket.

docs.title: v.25
docs.text: If you enter your neighbor's grainfield, you may pick kernels with your hands, but you must not put a sickle to his standing grain.

docs.title: v.1
docs.text: Moses and the elders of Israel commanded the people: "Keep all these commands that I give you today.

docs.title: v.2
docs.text: When you have crossed the Jordan into the land the LORD your God is giving you, set up some large stones and coat them with plaster.

docs.title: v.3
docs.text: Write on them all the words of this law when you have crossed over to enter the land the LORD your God is giving you, a land flowing with milk and honey, just as the LORD, the God of your fathers, promised you.

docs.title: v.4
docs.text: And when you have crossed the Jordan, set up these stones on Mount Ebal, as I command you today, and coat them with plaster.

docs.title: v.5
docs.text: Build there an altar to the LORD your God, an altar of stones. Do not use any iron tool upon them.

docs.title: v.6
docs.text: Build the altar of the LORD your God with fieldstones and offer burnt offerings on it to the LORD your God.

docs.title: v.7
docs.text: Sacrifice fellowship offerings there, eating them and rejoicing in the presence of the LORD your God.

docs.title: v.8
docs.text: And you shall write very clearly all the words of this law on these stones you have set up."

docs.title: v.9
docs.text: Then Moses and the priests, who are Levites, said to all Israel, "Be silent, O Israel, and listen! You have now become the people of the LORD your God.

docs.title: v.10
docs.text: Obey the LORD your God and follow his commands and decrees that I give you today."

docs.title: v.11
docs.text: On the same day Moses commanded the people:

docs.title: v.12
docs.text: When you have crossed the Jordan, these tribes shall stand on Mount Gerizim to bless the people: Simeon, Levi, Judah, Issachar, Joseph and Benjamin.

docs.title: v.13
docs.text: And these tribes shall stand on Mount Ebal to pronounce curses: Reuben, Gad, Asher, Zebulun, Dan and Naphtali.

docs.title: v.14
docs.text: The Levites shall recite to all the people of Israel in a loud voice:

docs.title: v.15
docs.text: "Cursed is the man who carves an image or casts an idol—a thing detestable to the LORD, the work of the craftsman's hands—and sets it up in secret." Then all the people shall say, "Amen!"

docs.title: v.16
docs.text: "Cursed is the man who dishonors his father or his mother." Then all the people shall say, "Amen!"

docs.title: v.17
docs.text: "Cursed is the man who moves his neighbor's boundary stone." Then all the people shall say, "Amen!"

docs.title: v.18
docs.text: "Cursed is the man who leads the blind astray on the road." Then all the people shall say, "Amen!"

docs.title: v.19
docs.text: "Cursed is the man who withholds justice from the alien, the fatherless or the widow." Then all the people shall say, "Amen!"

docs.title: v.20
docs.text: "Cursed is the man who sleeps with his father's wife, for he dishonors his father's bed." Then all the people shall say, "Amen!"

docs.title: v.21
docs.text: "Cursed is the man who has sexual relations with any animal." Then all the people shall say, "Amen!"

docs.title: v.22
docs.text: "Cursed is the man who sleeps with his sister, the daughter of his father or the daughter of his mother." Then all the people shall say, "Amen!"

docs.title: v.23
docs.text: "Cursed is the man who sleeps with his mother-in-law." Then all the people shall say, "Amen!"

docs.title: v.24
docs.text: "Cursed is the man who kills his neighbor secretly." Then all the people shall say, "Amen!"

docs.title: v.25
docs.text: "Cursed is the man who accepts a bribe to kill an innocent person." Then all the people shall say, "Amen!"

docs.title: v.26
docs.text: "Cursed is the man who does not uphold the words of this law by carrying them out." Then all the people shall say, "Amen!"

docs.title: v.1
docs.text: These are the terms of the covenant the LORD commanded Moses to make with the Israelites in Moab, in addition to the covenant he had made with them at Horeb.

docs.title: v.2
docs.text: Moses summoned all the Israelites and said to them: Your eyes have seen all that the LORD did in Egypt to Pharaoh, to all his officials and to all his land.

docs.title: v.3
docs.text: With your own eyes you saw those great trials, those miraculous signs and great wonders.

docs.title: v.4
docs.text: But to this day the LORD has not given you a mind that understands or eyes that see or ears that hear.

docs.title: v.5
docs.text: During the forty years that I led you through the desert, your clothes did not wear out, nor did the sandals on your feet.

docs.title: v.6
docs.text: You ate no bread and drank no wine or other fermented drink. I did this so that you might know that I am the LORD your God.

docs.title: v.7
docs.text: When you reached this place, Sihon king of Heshbon and Og king of Bashan came out to fight against us, but we defeated them.

docs.title: v.8
docs.text: We took their land and gave it as an inheritance to the Reubenites, the Gadites and the half-tribe of Manasseh.

docs.title: v.9
docs.text: Carefully follow the terms of this covenant, so that you may prosper in everything you do.

docs.title: v.10
docs.text: All of you are standing today in the presence of the LORD your God—your leaders and chief men, your elders and officials, and all the other men of Israel,

docs.title: v.11
docs.text: together with your children and your wives, and the aliens living in your camps who chop your wood and carry your water.

docs.title: v.12
docs.text: You are standing here in order to enter into a covenant with the LORD your God, a covenant the LORD is making with you this day and sealing with an oath,

docs.title: v.13
docs.text: to confirm you this day as his people, that he may be your God as he promised you and as he swore to your fathers, Abraham, Isaac and Jacob.

docs.title: v.14
docs.text: I am making this covenant, with its oath, not only with you

docs.title: v.15
docs.text: who are standing here with us today in the presence of the LORD our God but also with those who are not here today.

docs.title: v.16
docs.text: You yourselves know how we lived in Egypt and how we passed through the countries on the way here.

docs.title: v.17
docs.text: You saw among them their detestable images and idols of wood and stone, of silver and gold.

docs.title: v.18
docs.text: Make sure there is no man or woman, clan or tribe among you today whose heart turns away from the LORD our God to go and worship the gods of those nations; make sure there is no root among you that produces such bitter poison.

docs.title: v.19
docs.text: When such a person hears the words of this oath, he invokes a blessing on himself and therefore thinks, "I will be safe, even though I persist in going my own way." This will bring disaster on the watered land as well as the dry.

docs.title: v.20
docs.text: The LORD will never be willing to forgive him; his wrath and zeal will burn against that man. All the curses written in this book will fall upon him, and the LORD will blot out his name from under heaven.

docs.title: v.21
docs.text: The LORD will single him out from all the tribes of Israel for disaster, according to all the curses of the covenant written in this Book of the Law.

docs.title: v.22
docs.text: Your children who follow you in later generations and foreigners who come from distant lands will see the calamities that have fallen on the land and the diseases with which the LORD has afflicted it.

docs.title: v.23
docs.text: The whole land will be a burning waste of salt and sulfur—nothing planted, nothing sprouting, no vegetation growing on it. It will be like the destruction of Sodom and Gomorrah, Admah and Zeboiim, which the LORD overthrew in fierce anger.

docs.title: v.24
docs.text: All the nations will ask: "Why has the LORD done this to this land? Why this fierce, burning anger?"

docs.title: v.25
docs.text: And the answer will be: "It is because this people abandoned the covenant of the LORD, the God of their fathers, the covenant he made with them when he brought them out of Egypt.

docs.title: v.26
docs.text: They went off and worshiped other gods and bowed down to them, gods they did not know, gods he had not given them.

docs.title: v.27
docs.text: Therefore the LORD's anger burned against this land, so that he brought on it all the curses written in this book.

docs.title: v.28
docs.text: In furious anger and in great wrath the LORD uprooted them from their land and thrust them into another land, as it is now."

docs.title: v.29
docs.text: The secret things belong to the LORD our God, but the things revealed belong to us and to our children forever, that we may follow all the words of this law.

docs.title: v.1
docs.text: Next we turned and went up along the road toward Bashan, and Og king of Bashan with his whole army marched out to meet us in battle at Edrei.

docs.title: v.2
docs.text: The LORD said to me, "Do not be afraid of him, for I have handed him over to you with his whole army and his land. Do to him what you did to Sihon king of the Amorites, who reigned in Heshbon."

docs.title: v.3
docs.text: So the LORD our God also gave into our hands Og king of Bashan and all his army. We struck them down, leaving no survivors.

docs.title: v.4
docs.text: At that time we took all his cities. There was not one of the sixty cities that we did not take from them—the whole region of Argob, Og's kingdom in Bashan.

docs.title: v.5
docs.text: All these cities were fortified with high walls and with gates and bars, and there were also a great many unwalled villages.

docs.title: v.6
docs.text: We completely destroyed them, as we had done with Sihon king of Heshbon, destroying every city—men, women and children.

docs.title: v.7
docs.text: But all the livestock and the plunder from their cities we carried off for ourselves.

docs.title: v.8
docs.text: So at that time we took from these two kings of the Amorites the territory east of the Jordan, from the Arnon Gorge as far as Mount Hermon.

docs.title: v.9
docs.text: (Hermon is called Sirion by the Sidonians; the Amorites call it Senir.)

docs.title: v.10
docs.text: We took all the towns on the plateau, and all Gilead, and all Bashan as far as Salecah and Edrei, towns of Og's kingdom in Bashan.

docs.title: v.11
docs.text: (Only Og king of Bashan was left of the remnant of the Rephaites. His bed was made of iron and was more than thirteen feet long and six feet wide. It is still in Rabbah of the Ammonites.)

docs.title: v.12
docs.text: Of the land that we took over at that time, I gave the Reubenites and the Gadites the territory north of Aroer by the Arnon Gorge, including half the hill country of Gilead, together with its towns.

docs.title: v.13
docs.text: The rest of Gilead and also all of Bashan, the kingdom of Og, I gave to the half tribe of Manasseh. (The whole region of Argob in Bashan used to be known as a land of the Rephaites.

docs.title: v.14
docs.text: Jair, a descendant of Manasseh, took the whole region of Argob as far as the border of the Geshurites and the Maacathites; it was named after him, so that to this day Bashan is called Havvoth Jair. )

docs.title: v.15
docs.text: And I gave Gilead to Makir.

docs.title: v.16
docs.text: But to the Reubenites and the Gadites I gave the territory extending from Gilead down to the Arnon Gorge (the middle of the gorge being the border) and out to the Jabbok River, which is the border of the Ammonites.

docs.title: v.17
docs.text: Its western border was the Jordan in the Arabah, from Kinnereth to the Sea of the Arabah (the Salt Sea ), below the slopes of Pisgah.

docs.title: v.18
docs.text: I commanded you at that time: "The LORD your God has given you this land to take possession of it. But all your able-bodied men, armed for battle, must cross over ahead of your brother Israelites.

docs.title: v.19
docs.text: However, your wives, your children and your livestock (I know you have much livestock) may stay in the towns I have given you,

docs.title: v.20
docs.text: until the LORD gives rest to your brothers as he has to you, and they too have taken over the land that the LORD your God is giving them, across the Jordan. After that, each of you may go back to the possession I have given you."

docs.title: v.21
docs.text: At that time I commanded Joshua: "You have seen with your own eyes all that the LORD your God has done to these two kings. The LORD will do the same to all the kingdoms over there where you are going.

docs.title: v.22
docs.text: Do not be afraid of them; the LORD your God himself will fight for you."

docs.title: v.23
docs.text: At that time I pleaded with the LORD:

docs.title: v.24
docs.text: "O Sovereign LORD, you have begun to show to your servant your greatness and your strong hand. For what god is there in heaven or on earth who can do the deeds and mighty works you do?

docs.title: v.25
docs.text: Let me go over and see the good land beyond the Jordan—that fine hill country and Lebanon."

docs.title: v.26
docs.text: But because of you the LORD was angry with me and would not listen to me. "That is enough," the LORD said. "Do not speak to me anymore about this matter.

docs.title: v.27
docs.text: Go up to the top of Pisgah and look west and north and south and east. Look at the land with your own eyes, since you are not going to cross this Jordan.

docs.title: v.28
docs.text: But commission Joshua, and encourage and strengthen him, for he will lead this people across and will cause them to inherit the land that you will see."

docs.title: v.29
docs.text: So we stayed in the valley near Beth Peor.

docs.title: v.1
docs.text: When all these blessings and curses I have set before you come upon you and you take them to heart wherever the LORD your God disperses you among the nations,

docs.title: v.2
docs.text: and when you and your children return to the LORD your God and obey him with all your heart and with all your soul according to everything I command you today,

docs.title: v.3
docs.text: then the LORD your God will restore your fortunes and have compassion on you and gather you again from all the nations where he scattered you.

docs.title: v.4
docs.text: Even if you have been banished to the most distant land under the heavens, from there the LORD your God will gather you and bring you back.

docs.title: v.5
docs.text: He will bring you to the land that belonged to your fathers, and you will take possession of it. He will make you more prosperous and numerous than your fathers.

docs.title: v.6
docs.text: The LORD your God will circumcise your hearts and the hearts of your descendants, so that you may love him with all your heart and with all your soul, and live.

docs.title: v.7
docs.text: The LORD your God will put all these curses on your enemies who hate and persecute you.

docs.title: v.8
docs.text: You will again obey the LORD and follow all his commands I am giving you today.

docs.title: v.9
docs.text: Then the LORD your God will make you most prosperous in all the work of your hands and in the fruit of your womb, the young of your livestock and the crops of your land. The LORD will again delight in you and make you prosperous, just as he delighted in your fathers,

docs.title: v.10
docs.text: if you obey the LORD your God and keep his commands and decrees that are written in this Book of the Law and turn to the LORD your God with all your heart and with all your soul.

docs.title: v.11
docs.text: Now what I am commanding you today is not too difficult for you or beyond your reach.

docs.title: v.12
docs.text: It is not up in heaven, so that you have to ask, "Who will ascend into heaven to get it and proclaim it to us so we may obey it?"

docs.title: v.13
docs.text: Nor is it beyond the sea, so that you have to ask, "Who will cross the sea to get it and proclaim it to us so we may obey it?"

docs.title: v.14
docs.text: No, the word is very near you; it is in your mouth and in your heart so you may obey it.

docs.title: v.15
docs.text: See, I set before you today life and prosperity, death and destruction.

docs.title: v.16
docs.text: For I command you today to love the LORD your God, to walk in his ways, and to keep his commands, decrees and laws; then you will live and increase, and the LORD your God will bless you in the land you are entering to possess.

docs.title: v.17
docs.text: But if your heart turns away and you are not obedient, and if you are drawn away to bow down to other gods and worship them,

docs.title: v.18
docs.text: I declare to you this day that you will certainly be destroyed. You will not live long in the land you are crossing the Jordan to enter and possess.

docs.title: v.19
docs.text: This day I call heaven and earth as witnesses against you that I have set before you life and death, blessings and curses. Now choose life, so that you and your children may live

docs.title: v.20
docs.text: and that you may love the LORD your God, listen to his voice, and hold fast to him. For the LORD is your life, and he will give you many years in the land he swore to give to your fathers, Abraham, Isaac and Jacob.

docs.title: v.1
docs.text: Listen, O heavens, and I will speak; hear, O earth, the words of my mouth.

docs.title: v.2
docs.text: Let my teaching fall like rain and my words descend like dew, like showers on new grass, like abundant rain on tender plants.

docs.title: v.3
docs.text: I will proclaim the name of the LORD. Oh, praise the greatness of our God!

docs.title: v.4
docs.text: He is the Rock, his works are perfect, and all his ways are just. A faithful God who does no wrong, upright and just is he.

docs.title: v.5
docs.text: They have acted corruptly toward him; to their shame they are no longer his children, but a warped and crooked generation.

docs.title: v.6
docs.text: Is this the way you repay the LORD, O foolish and unwise people? Is he not your Father, your Creator, who made you and formed you?

docs.title: v.7
docs.text: Remember the days of old; consider the generations long past. Ask your father and he will tell you, your elders, and they will explain to you.

docs.title: v.8
docs.text: When the Most High gave the nations their inheritance, when he divided all mankind, he set up boundaries for the peoples according to the number of the sons of Israel.

docs.title: v.9
docs.text: For the LORD's portion is his people, Jacob his allotted inheritance.

docs.title: v.10
docs.text: In a desert land he found him, in a barren and howling waste. He shielded him and cared for him; he guarded him as the apple of his eye,

docs.title: v.11
docs.text: like an eagle that stirs up its nest and hovers over its young, that spreads its wings to catch them and carries them on its pinions.

docs.title: v.12
docs.text: The LORD alone led him; no foreign god was with him.

docs.title: v.13
docs.text: He made him ride on the heights of the land and fed him with the fruit of the fields. He nourished him with honey from the rock, and with oil from the flinty crag,

docs.title: v.14
docs.text: with curds and milk from herd and flock and with fattened lambs and goats, with choice rams of Bashan and the finest kernels of wheat. You drank the foaming blood of the grape.

docs.title: v.15
docs.text: Jeshurun grew fat and kicked; filled with food, he became heavy and sleek. He abandoned the God who made him and rejected the Rock his Savior.

docs.title: v.16
docs.text: They made him jealous with their foreign gods and angered him with their detestable idols.

docs.title: v.17
docs.text: They sacrificed to demons, which are not God— gods they had not known, gods that recently appeared, gods your fathers did not fear.

docs.title: v.18
docs.text: You deserted the Rock, who fathered you; you forgot the God who gave you birth.

docs.title: v.19
docs.text: The LORD saw this and rejected them because he was angered by his sons and daughters.

docs.title: v.20
docs.text: "I will hide my face from them," he said, "and see what their end will be; for they are a perverse generation, children who are unfaithful.

docs.title: v.21
docs.text: They made me jealous by what is no god and angered me with their worthless idols. I will make them envious by those who are not a people; I will make them angry by a nation that has no understanding.

docs.title: v.22
docs.text: For a fire has been kindled by my wrath, one that burns to the realm of death below. It will devour the earth and its harvests and set afire the foundations of the mountains.

docs.title: v.23
docs.text: "I will heap calamities upon them and spend my arrows against them.

docs.title: v.24
docs.text: I will send wasting famine against them, consuming pestilence and deadly plague; I will send against them the fangs of wild beasts, the venom of vipers that glide in the dust.

docs.title: v.25
docs.text: In the street the sword will make them childless; in their homes terror will reign. Young men and young women will perish, infants and gray-haired men.

docs.title: v.26
docs.text: I said I would scatter them and blot out their memory from mankind,

docs.title: v.27
docs.text: but I dreaded the taunt of the enemy, lest the adversary misunderstand and say, 'Our hand has triumphed; the LORD has not done all this.'"

docs.title: v.28
docs.text: They are a nation without sense, there is no discernment in them.

docs.title: v.29
docs.text: If only they were wise and would understand this and discern what their end will be!

docs.title: v.30
docs.text: How could one man chase a thousand, or two put ten thousand to flight, unless their Rock had sold them, unless the LORD had given them up?

docs.title: v.31
docs.text: For their rock is not like our Rock, as even our enemies concede.

docs.title: v.32
docs.text: Their vine comes from the vine of Sodom and from the fields of Gomorrah. Their grapes are filled with poison, and their clusters with bitterness.

docs.title: v.33
docs.text: Their wine is the venom of serpents, the deadly poison of cobras.

docs.title: v.34
docs.text: "Have I not kept this in reserve and sealed it in my vaults?

docs.title: v.35
docs.text: It is mine to avenge; I will repay. In due time their foot will slip; their day of disaster is near and their doom rushes upon them."

docs.title: v.36
docs.text: The LORD will judge his people and have compassion on his servants when he sees their strength is gone and no one is left, slave or free.

docs.title: v.37
docs.text: He will say: "Now where are their gods, the rock they took refuge in,

docs.title: v.38
docs.text: the gods who ate the fat of their sacrifices and drank the wine of their drink offerings? Let them rise up to help you! Let them give you shelter!

docs.title: v.39
docs.text: "See now that I myself am He! There is no god besides me. I put to death and I bring to life, I have wounded and I will heal, and no one can deliver out of my hand.

docs.title: v.40
docs.text: I lift my hand to heaven and declare: As surely as I live forever,

docs.title: v.41
docs.text: when I sharpen my flashing sword and my hand grasps it in judgment, I will take vengeance on my adversaries and repay those who hate me.

docs.title: v.42
docs.text: I will make my arrows drunk with blood, while my sword devours flesh: the blood of the slain and the captives, the heads of the enemy leaders."

docs.title: v.43
docs.text: Rejoice, O nations, with his people, for he will avenge the blood of his servants; he will take vengeance on his enemies and make atonement for his land and people.

docs.title: v.44
docs.text: Moses came with Joshua son of Nun and spoke all the words of this song in the hearing of the people.

docs.title: v.45
docs.text: When Moses finished reciting all these words to all Israel,

docs.title: v.46
docs.text: he said to them, "Take to heart all the words I have solemnly declared to you this day, so that you may command your children to obey carefully all the words of this law.

docs.title: v.47
docs.text: They are not just idle words for you—they are your life. By them you will live long in the land you are crossing the Jordan to possess."

docs.title: v.48
docs.text: On that same day the LORD told Moses,

docs.title: v.49
docs.text: "Go up into the Abarim Range to Mount Nebo in Moab, across from Jericho, and view Canaan, the land I am giving the Israelites as their own possession.

docs.title: v.50
docs.text: There on the mountain that you have climbed you will die and be gathered to your people, just as your brother Aaron died on Mount Hor and was gathered to his people.

docs.title: v.51
docs.text: This is because both of you broke faith with me in the presence of the Israelites at the waters of Meribah Kadesh in the Desert of Zin and because you did not uphold my holiness among the Israelites.

docs.title: v.52
docs.text: Therefore, you will see the land only from a distance; you will not enter the land I am giving to the people of Israel."

docs.title: v.1
docs.text: Hear now, O Israel, the decrees and laws I am about to teach you. Follow them so that you may live and may go in and take possession of the land that the LORD, the God of your fathers, is giving you.

docs.title: v.2
docs.text: Do not add to what I command you and do not subtract from it, but keep the commands of the LORD your God that I give you.

docs.title: v.3
docs.text: You saw with your own eyes what the LORD did at Baal Peor. The LORD your God destroyed from among you everyone who followed the Baal of Peor,

docs.title: v.4
docs.text: but all of you who held fast to the LORD your God are still alive today.

docs.title: v.5
docs.text: See, I have taught you decrees and laws as the LORD my God commanded me, so that you may follow them in the land you are entering to take possession of it.

docs.title: v.6
docs.text: Observe them carefully, for this will show your wisdom and understanding to the nations, who will hear about all these decrees and say, "Surely this great nation is a wise and understanding people."

docs.title: v.7
docs.text: What other nation is so great as to have their gods near them the way the LORD our God is near us whenever we pray to him?

docs.title: v.8
docs.text: And what other nation is so great as to have such righteous decrees and laws as this body of laws I am setting before you today?

docs.title: v.9
docs.text: Only be careful, and watch yourselves closely so that you do not forget the things your eyes have seen or let them slip from your heart as long as you live. Teach them to your children and to their children after them.

docs.title: v.10
docs.text: Remember the day you stood before the LORD your God at Horeb, when he said to me, "Assemble the people before me to hear my words so that they may learn to revere me as long as they live in the land and may teach them to their children."

docs.title: v.11
docs.text: You came near and stood at the foot of the mountain while it blazed with fire to the very heavens, with black clouds and deep darkness.

docs.title: v.12
docs.text: Then the LORD spoke to you out of the fire. You heard the sound of words but saw no form; there was only a voice.

docs.title: v.13
docs.text: He declared to you his covenant, the Ten Commandments, which he commanded you to follow and then wrote them on two stone tablets.

docs.title: v.14
docs.text: And the LORD directed me at that time to teach you the decrees and laws you are to follow in the land that you are crossing the Jordan to possess.

docs.title: v.15
docs.text: You saw no form of any kind the day the LORD spoke to you at Horeb out of the fire. Therefore watch yourselves very carefully,

docs.title: v.16
docs.text: so that you do not become corrupt and make for yourselves an idol, an image of any shape, whether formed like a man or a woman,

docs.title: v.17
docs.text: or like any animal on earth or any bird that flies in the air,

docs.title: v.18
docs.text: or like any creature that moves along the ground or any fish in the waters below.

docs.title: v.19
docs.text: And when you look up to the sky and see the sun, the moon and the stars—all the heavenly array—do not be enticed into bowing down to them and worshiping things the LORD your God has apportioned to all the nations under heaven.

docs.title: v.20
docs.text: But as for you, the LORD took you and brought you out of the iron-smelting furnace, out of Egypt, to be the people of his inheritance, as you now are.

docs.title: v.21
docs.text: The LORD was angry with me because of you, and he solemnly swore that I would not cross the Jordan and enter the good land the LORD your God is giving you as your inheritance.

docs.title: v.22
docs.text: I will die in this land; I will not cross the Jordan; but you are about to cross over and take possession of that good land.

docs.title: v.23
docs.text: Be careful not to forget the covenant of the LORD your God that he made with you; do not make for yourselves an idol in the form of anything the LORD your God has forbidden.

docs.title: v.24
docs.text: For the LORD your God is a consuming fire, a jealous God.

docs.title: v.25
docs.text: After you have had children and grandchildren and have lived in the land a long time—if you then become corrupt and make any kind of idol, doing evil in the eyes of the LORD your God and provoking him to anger,

docs.title: v.26
docs.text: I call heaven and earth as witnesses against you this day that you will quickly perish from the land that you are crossing the Jordan to possess. You will not live there long but will certainly be destroyed.

docs.title: v.27
docs.text: The LORD will scatter you among the peoples, and only a few of you will survive among the nations to which the LORD will drive you.

docs.title: v.28
docs.text: There you will worship man-made gods of wood and stone, which cannot see or hear or eat or smell.

docs.title: v.29
docs.text: But if from there you seek the LORD your God, you will find him if you look for him with all your heart and with all your soul.

docs.title: v.30
docs.text: When you are in distress and all these things have happened to you, then in later days you will return to the LORD your God and obey him.

docs.title: v.31
docs.text: For the LORD your God is a merciful God; he will not abandon or destroy you or forget the covenant with your forefathers, which he confirmed to them by oath.

docs.title: v.32
docs.text: Ask now about the former days, long before your time, from the day God created man on the earth; ask from one end of the heavens to the other. Has anything so great as this ever happened, or has anything like it ever been heard of?

docs.title: v.33
docs.text: Has any other people heard the voice of God speaking out of fire, as you have, and lived?

docs.title: v.34
docs.text: Has any god ever tried to take for himself one nation out of another nation, by testings, by miraculous signs and wonders, by war, by a mighty hand and an outstretched arm, or by great and awesome deeds, like all the things the LORD your God did for you in Egypt before your very eyes?

docs.title: v.35
docs.text: You were shown these things so that you might know that the LORD is God; besides him there is no other.

docs.title: v.36
docs.text: From heaven he made you hear his voice to discipline you. On earth he showed you his great fire, and you heard his words from out of the fire.

docs.title: v.37
docs.text: Because he loved your forefathers and chose their descendants after them, he brought you out of Egypt by his Presence and his great strength,

docs.title: v.38
docs.text: to drive out before you nations greater and stronger than you and to bring you into their land to give it to you for your inheritance, as it is today.

docs.title: v.39
docs.text: Acknowledge and take to heart this day that the LORD is God in heaven above and on the earth below. There is no other.

docs.title: v.40
docs.text: Keep his decrees and commands, which I am giving you today, so that it may go well with you and your children after you and that you may live long in the land the LORD your God gives you for all time.

docs.title: v.41
docs.text: Then Moses set aside three cities east of the Jordan,

docs.title: v.42
docs.text: to which anyone who had killed a person could flee if he had unintentionally killed his neighbor without malice aforethought. He could flee into one of these cities and save his life.

docs.title: v.43
docs.text: The cities were these: Bezer in the desert plateau, for the Reubenites; Ramoth in Gilead, for the Gadites; and Golan in Bashan, for the Manassites.

docs.title: v.44
docs.text: This is the law Moses set before the Israelites.

docs.title: v.45
docs.text: These are the stipulations, decrees and laws Moses gave them when they came out of Egypt

docs.title: v.46
docs.text: and were in the valley near Beth Peor east of the Jordan, in the land of Sihon king of the Amorites, who reigned in Heshbon and was defeated by Moses and the Israelites as they came out of Egypt.

docs.title: v.47
docs.text: They took possession of his land and the land of Og king of Bashan, the two Amorite kings east of the Jordan.

docs.title: v.48
docs.text: This land extended from Aroer on the rim of the Arnon Gorge to Mount Siyon (that is, Hermon),

docs.title: v.49
docs.text: and included all the Arabah east of the Jordan, as far as the Sea of the Arabah, below the slopes of Pisgah.

docs.title: v.1
docs.text: Moses summoned all Israel and said: Hear, O Israel, the decrees and laws I declare in your hearing today. Learn them and be sure to follow them.

docs.title: v.2
docs.text: The LORD our God made a covenant with us at Horeb.

docs.title: v.3
docs.text: It was not with our fathers that the LORD made this covenant, but with us, with all of us who are alive here today.

docs.title: v.4
docs.text: The LORD spoke to you face to face out of the fire on the mountain.

docs.title: v.5
docs.text: (At that time I stood between the LORD and you to declare to you the word of the LORD, because you were afraid of the fire and did not go up the mountain.) And he said:

docs.title: v.6
docs.text: "I am the LORD your God, who brought you out of Egypt, out of the land of slavery.

docs.title: v.7
docs.text: "You shall have no other gods before me.

docs.title: v.8
docs.text: "You shall not make for yourself an idol in the form of anything in heaven above or on the earth beneath or in the waters below.

docs.title: v.9-10
docs.text: You shall not bow down to them or worship them; for I, the LORD your God, am a jealous God, punishing the children for the sin of the fathers to the third and fourth generation of those who hate me, 10but showing love to a thousand [generations] of those who love me and keep my commandments.

docs.title: v.11
docs.text: "You shall not misuse the name of the LORD your God, for the LORD will not hold anyone guiltless who misuses his name.

docs.title: v.12
docs.text: "Observe the Sabbath day by keeping it holy, as the LORD your God has commanded you.

docs.title: v.13
docs.text: Six days you shall labor and do all your work,

docs.title: v.14
docs.text: but the seventh day is a Sabbath to the LORD your God. On it you shall not do any work, neither you, nor your son or daughter, nor your manservant or maidservant, nor your ox, your donkey or any of your animals, nor the alien within your gates, so that your manservant and maidservant may rest, as you do.

docs.title: v.15
docs.text: Remember that you were slaves in Egypt and that the LORD your God brought you out of there with a mighty hand and an outstretched arm. Therefore the LORD your God has commanded you to observe the Sabbath day.

docs.title: v.16
docs.text: "Honor your father and your mother, as the LORD your God has commanded you, so that you may live long and that it may go well with you in the land the LORD your God is giving you.

docs.title: v.17
docs.text: "You shall not murder.

docs.title: v.18
docs.text: "You shall not commit adultery.

docs.title: v.19
docs.text: "You shall not steal.

docs.title: v.20
docs.text: "You shall not give false testimony against your neighbor.

docs.title: v.21
docs.text: "You shall not covet your neighbor's wife. You shall not set your desire on your neighbor's house or land, his manservant or maidservant, his ox or donkey, or anything that belongs to your neighbor."

docs.title: v.22
docs.text: These are the commandments the LORD proclaimed in a loud voice to your whole assembly there on the mountain from out of the fire, the cloud and the deep darkness; and he added nothing more. Then he wrote them on two stone tablets and gave them to me.

docs.title: v.23
docs.text: When you heard the voice out of the darkness, while the mountain was ablaze with fire, all the leading men of your tribes and your elders came to me.

docs.title: v.24
docs.text: And you said, "The LORD our God has shown us his glory and his majesty, and we have heard his voice from the fire. Today we have seen that a man can live even if God speaks with him.

docs.title: v.25
docs.text: But now, why should we die? This great fire will consume us, and we will die if we hear the voice of the LORD our God any longer.

docs.title: v.26
docs.text: For what mortal man has ever heard the voice of the living God speaking out of fire, as we have, and survived?

docs.title: v.27
docs.text: Go near and listen to all that the LORD our God says. Then tell us whatever the LORD our God tells you. We will listen and obey."

docs.title: v.28
docs.text: The LORD heard you when you spoke to me and the LORD said to me, "I have heard what this people said to you. Everything they said was good.

docs.title: v.29
docs.text: Oh, that their hearts would be inclined to fear me and keep all my commands always, so that it might go well with them and their children forever!

docs.title: v.30
docs.text: "Go, tell them to return to their tents.

docs.title: v.31
docs.text: But you stay here with me so that I may give you all the commands, decrees and laws you are to teach them to follow in the land I am giving them to possess."

docs.title: v.32
docs.text: So be careful to do what the LORD your God has commanded you; do not turn aside to the right or to the left.

docs.title: v.33
docs.text: Walk in all the way that the LORD your God has commanded you, so that you may live and prosper and prolong your days in the land that you will possess.

docs.title: v.16
docs.text: Do not test the Lord your God as you did at Massah.

docs.title: v.1
docs.text: When the LORD your God brings you into the land you are entering to possess and drives out before you many nations—the Hittites, Girgashites, Amorites, Canaanites, Perizzites, Hivites and Jebusites, seven nations larger and stronger than you—

docs.title: v.2
docs.text: and when the LORD your God has delivered them over to you and you have defeated them, then you must destroy them totally. Make no treaty with them, and show them no mercy.

docs.title: v.3
docs.text: Do not intermarry with them. Do not give your daughters to their sons or take their daughters for your sons,

docs.title: v.4
docs.text: for they will turn your sons away from following me to serve other gods, and the LORD's anger will burn against you and will quickly destroy you.

docs.title: v.5
docs.text: This is what you are to do to them: Break down their altars, smash their sacred stones, cut down their Asherah poles and burn their idols in the fire.

docs.title: v.6
docs.text: For you are a people holy to the LORD your God. The LORD your God has chosen you out of all the peoples on the face of the earth to be his people, his treasured possession.

docs.title: v.7
docs.text: The LORD did not set his affection on you and choose you because you were more numerous than other peoples, for you were the fewest of all peoples.

docs.title: v.8
docs.text: But it was because the LORD loved you and kept the oath he swore to your forefathers that he brought you out with a mighty hand and redeemed you from the land of slavery, from the power of Pharaoh king of Egypt.

docs.title: v.9
docs.text:
Know therefore that the LORD your God is God; he is the faithful God, keeping his covenant of love to a thousand generations of those who love him and keep his commands.

Love (Heb. hesed, mercy, steadfast love, loyalty, covenant love) is the epoxy that binds people and God together. Note the amazing grace of God expressed in the Decalogue where the thousand generations to whom God's covenant love is applied is placed in contrast to God's punishing the iniquity of the fathers on the children to the third and fourth generation of those who hate him (Exod. 20:5-6; Deut. 5:9-10). Such a high calling is often accompanied by pride and boastfulness (problems which Moses deals with in chaps. 8-10). Israel is not to presume on God's covenant love and grace, for carelessness only leads to destruction as a further exhibit of God's justice.

docs.title: v.10
docs.text: But those who hate him he will repay to their face by destruction; he will not be slow to repay to their face those who hate him.

docs.title: v.11
docs.text: Therefore, take care to follow the commands, decrees and laws I give you today.

docs.title: v.12
docs.text: If you pay attention to these laws and are careful to follow them, then the LORD your God will keep his covenant of love with you, as he swore to your forefathers.

docs.title: v.13
docs.text: He will love you and bless you and increase your numbers. He will bless the fruit of your womb, the crops of your land—your grain, new wine and oil—the calves of your herds and the lambs of your flocks in the land that he swore to your forefathers to give you.

docs.title: v.14
docs.text:
You will be blessed more than any other people; none of your men or women will be childless, nor any of your livestock without young.

It is not Baal, but Yahweh who freely bestows fertility and blessings on crops, family, and flocks.

docs.title: v.15
docs.text:
The LORD will keep you free from every disease. He will not inflict on you the horrible diseases you knew in Egypt, but he will inflict them on all who hate you.

The diseases in Egypt were God's judgement on a rebellious nation, but the same God will turn the curse into a blessing.

docs.title: v.16
docs.text: You must destroy all the peoples the LORD your God gives over to you. Do not look on them with pity and do not serve their gods, for that will be a snare to you.

docs.title: v.17
docs.text:
You may say to yourselves, "These nations are stronger than we are. How can we drive them out?" 18But do not be afraid of them; remember well what the LORD your God did to Pharaoh and to all Egypt.

The difficulties of conquest demand faith (7:17-26). If Israel's special status tempted them to become proud and boastful, the awesome responsibility of conquest would tempt them to become timid (Num. 13:31-33). Faith to overcome such temptation can only be attained through first recalling the miraculous signs and wonders, the mighty hand and outstretched arm of God in Egypt (vv. 18-19).

docs.title: v.19
docs.text: You saw with your own eyes the great trials, the miraculous signs and wonders, the mighty hand and outstretched arm, with which the LORD your God brought you out. The LORD your God will do the same to all the peoples you now fear.

docs.title: v.20
docs.text: Moreover, the LORD your God will send the hornet among them until even the survivors who hide from you have perished.

docs.title: v.21
docs.text: Do not be terrified by them, for the LORD your God, who is among you, is a great and awesome God.

docs.title: v.22
docs.text: The LORD your God will drive out those nations before you, little by little. You will not be allowed to eliminate them all at once, or the wild animals will multiply around you.

docs.title: v.23
docs.text: But the LORD your God will deliver them over to you, throwing them into great confusion until they are destroyed.

docs.title: v.24
docs.text: He will give their kings into your hand, and you will wipe out their names from under heaven. No one will be able to stand up against you; you will destroy them.

docs.title: v.25
docs.text: The images of their gods you are to burn in the fire. Do not covet the silver and gold on them, and do not take it for yourselves, or you will be ensnared by it, for it is detestable to the LORD your God.

docs.title: v.26
