docs.title: v.29
docs.text: "Summon archers against Babylon, all those who draw the bow. Encamp all around her; let no one escape. Repay her for her deeds; do to her as she has done. For she has defied the LORD, the Holy One of Israel.

docs.title: v.30
docs.text: Therefore, her young men will fall in the streets; all her soldiers will be silenced in that day," declares the LORD.

docs.title: v.31
docs.text: "See, I am against you, O arrogant one," declares the Lord, the LORD Almighty, "for your day has come, the time for you to be punished.

docs.title: v.32
docs.text: The arrogant one will stumble and fall and no one will help her up; I will kindle a fire in her towns that will consume all who are around her."

docs.title: v.33
docs.text: This is what the LORD Almighty says: "The people of Israel are oppressed, and the people of Judah as well. All their captors hold them fast, refusing to let them go.

docs.title: v.34
docs.text: Yet their Redeemer is strong; the LORD Almighty is his name. He will vigorously defend their cause so that he may bring rest to their land, but unrest to those who live in Babylon.

docs.title: v.35
docs.text: "A sword against the Babylonians!" declares the LORD— "against those who live in Babylon and against her officials and wise men!

docs.title: v.36
docs.text: A sword against her false prophets! They will become fools. A sword against her warriors! They will be filled with terror.

docs.title: v.37
docs.text: A sword against her horses and chariots and all the foreigners in her ranks! They will become women. A sword against her treasures! They will be plundered.

docs.title: v.38
docs.text: A drought on her waters! They will dry up. For it is a land of idols, idols that will go mad with terror.

docs.title: v.39
docs.text: "So desert creatures and hyenas will live there, and there the owl will dwell. It will never again be inhabited or lived in from generation to generation.

docs.title: v.40
docs.text: As God overthrew Sodom and Gomorrah along with their neighboring towns," declares the LORD, "so no one will live there; no man will dwell in it.

docs.title: v.41
docs.text: "Look! An army is coming from the north; a great nation and many kings are being stirred up from the ends of the earth.

docs.title: v.42
docs.text: They are armed with bows and spears; they are cruel and without mercy. They sound like the roaring sea as they ride on their horses; they come like men in battle formation to attack you, O Daughter of Babylon.

docs.title: v.43
docs.text: The king of Babylon has heard reports about them, and his hands hang limp. Anguish has gripped him, pain like that of a woman in labor.

docs.title: v.44
docs.text: Like a lion coming up from Jordan's thickets to a rich pastureland, I will chase Babylon from its land in an instant. Who is the chosen one I will appoint for this? Who is like me and who can challenge me? And what shepherd can stand against me?"

docs.title: v.45
docs.text: Therefore, hear what the LORD has planned against Babylon, what he has purposed against the land of the Babylonians: The young of the flock will be dragged away; he will completely destroy their pasture because of them.

docs.title: v.46
docs.text: At the sound of Babylon's capture the earth will tremble; its cry will resound among the nations.

docs.title: v.1
docs.text: This is what the LORD says: "See, I will stir up the spirit of a destroyer against Babylon and the people of Leb Kamai.

docs.title: v.2
docs.text: I will send foreigners to Babylon to winnow her and to devastate her land; they will oppose her on every side in the day of her disaster.

docs.title: v.3
docs.text: Let not the archer string his bow, nor let him put on his armor. Do not spare her young men; completely destroy her army.

docs.title: v.4
docs.text: They will fall down slain in Babylon, fatally wounded in her streets.

docs.title: v.5
docs.text: For Israel and Judah have not been forsaken by their God, the LORD Almighty, though their land is full of guilt before the Holy One of Israel.

docs.title: v.6
docs.text: "Flee from Babylon! Run for your lives! Do not be destroyed because of her sins. It is time for the LORD's vengeance; he will pay her what she deserves.

docs.title: v.7
docs.text: Babylon was a gold cup in the LORD's hand; she made the whole earth drunk. The nations drank her wine; therefore they have now gone mad.

docs.title: v.8
docs.text: Babylon will suddenly fall and be broken. Wail over her! Get balm for her pain; perhaps she can be healed.

docs.title: v.9
docs.text: "'We would have healed Babylon, but she cannot be healed; let us leave her and each go to his own land, for her judgment reaches to the skies, it rises as high as the clouds.'

docs.title: v.10
docs.text: "'The LORD has vindicated us; come, let us tell in Zion what the LORD our God has done.'

docs.title: v.11
docs.text: "Sharpen the arrows, take up the shields! The LORD has stirred up the kings of the Medes, because his purpose is to destroy Babylon. The LORD will take vengeance, vengeance for his temple.

docs.title: v.12
docs.text: Lift up a banner against the walls of Babylon! Reinforce the guard, station the watchmen, prepare an ambush! The LORD will carry out his purpose, his decree against the people of Babylon.

docs.title: v.13
docs.text: You who live by many waters and are rich in treasures, your end has come, the time for you to be cut off.

docs.title: v.14
docs.text: The LORD Almighty has sworn by himself: I will surely fill you with men, as with a swarm of locusts, and they will shout in triumph over you.

docs.title: v.15
docs.text: "He made the earth by his power; he founded the world by his wisdom and stretched out the heavens by his understanding.

docs.title: v.16
docs.text: When he thunders, the waters in the heavens roar; he makes clouds rise from the ends of the earth. He sends lightning with the rain and brings out the wind from his storehouses.

docs.title: v.17
docs.text: "Every man is senseless and without knowledge; every goldsmith is shamed by his idols. His images are a fraud; they have no breath in them.

docs.title: v.18
docs.text: They are worthless, the objects of mockery; when their judgment comes, they will perish.

docs.title: v.19
docs.text: He who is the Portion of Jacob is not like these, for he is the Maker of all things, including the tribe of his inheritance— the LORD Almighty is his name.

docs.title: v.20
docs.text: "You are my war club, my weapon for battle— with you I shatter nations, with you I destroy kingdoms,

docs.title: v.21
docs.text: with you I shatter horse and rider, with you I shatter chariot and driver,

docs.title: v.22
docs.text: with you I shatter man and woman, with you I shatter old man and youth, with you I shatter young man and maiden,

docs.title: v.23
docs.text: with you I shatter shepherd and flock, with you I shatter farmer and oxen, with you I shatter governors and officials.

docs.title: v.24
docs.text: "Before your eyes I will repay Babylon and all who live in Babylonia for all the wrong they have done in Zion," declares the LORD.

docs.title: v.25
docs.text: "I am against you, O destroying mountain, you who destroy the whole earth," declares the LORD. "I will stretch out my hand against you, roll you off the cliffs, and make you a burned-out mountain.

docs.title: v.26
docs.text: No rock will be taken from you for a cornerstone, nor any stone for a foundation, for you will be desolate forever," declares the LORD.

docs.title: v.27
docs.text: "Lift up a banner in the land! Blow the trumpet among the nations! Prepare the nations for battle against her; summon against her these kingdoms: Ararat, Minni and Ashkenaz. Appoint a commander against her; send up horses like a swarm of locusts.

docs.title: v.28
docs.text: Prepare the nations for battle against her— the kings of the Medes, their governors and all their officials, and all the countries they rule.

docs.title: v.29
docs.text: The land trembles and writhes, for the LORD's purposes against Babylon stand— to lay waste the land of Babylon so that no one will live there.

docs.title: v.30
docs.text: Babylon's warriors have stopped fighting; they remain in their strongholds. Their strength is exhausted; they have become like women. Her dwellings are set on fire; the bars of her gates are broken.

docs.title: v.31
docs.text: One courier follows another and messenger follows messenger to announce to the king of Babylon that his entire city is captured,

docs.title: v.32
docs.text: the river crossings seized, the marshes set on fire, and the soldiers terrified."

docs.title: v.33
docs.text: This is what the LORD Almighty, the God of Israel, says: "The Daughter of Babylon is like a threshing floor at the time it is trampled; the time to harvest her will soon come."

docs.title: v.34
docs.text: "Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon has devoured us, he has thrown us into confusion, he has made us an empty jar. Like a serpent he has swallowed us and filled his stomach with our delicacies, and then has spewed us out.

docs.title: v.35
docs.text: May the violence done to our flesh be upon Babylon," say the inhabitants of Zion. "May our blood be on those who live in Babylonia," says Jerusalem.

docs.title: v.36
docs.text: Therefore, this is what the LORD says: "See, I will defend your cause and avenge you; I will dry up her sea and make her springs dry.

docs.title: v.37
docs.text: Babylon will be a heap of ruins, a haunt of jackals, an object of horror and scorn, a place where no one lives.

docs.title: v.38
docs.text: Her people all roar like young lions, they growl like lion cubs.

docs.title: v.39
docs.text: But while they are aroused, I will set out a feast for them and make them drunk, so that they shout with laughter— then sleep forever and not awake," declares the LORD.

docs.title: v.40
docs.text: "I will bring them down like lambs to the slaughter, like rams and goats.

docs.title: v.41
docs.text: "How Sheshach will be captured, the boast of the whole earth seized! What a horror Babylon will be among the nations!

docs.title: v.42
docs.text: The sea will rise over Babylon; its roaring waves will cover her.

docs.title: v.43
docs.text: Her towns will be desolate, a dry and desert land, a land where no one lives, through which no man travels.

docs.title: v.44
docs.text: I will punish Bel in Babylon and make him spew out what he has swallowed. The nations will no longer stream to him. And the wall of Babylon will fall.

docs.title: v.45
docs.text: "Come out of her, my people! Run for your lives! Run from the fierce anger of the LORD.

docs.title: v.46
docs.text: Do not lose heart or be afraid when rumors are heard in the land; one rumor comes this year, another the next, rumors of violence in the land and of ruler against ruler.

docs.title: v.47
docs.text: For the time will surely come when I will punish the idols of Babylon; her whole land will be disgraced and her slain will all lie fallen within her.

docs.title: v.48
docs.text: Then heaven and earth and all that is in them will shout for joy over Babylon, for out of the north destroyers will attack her," declares the LORD.

docs.title: v.49
docs.text: "Babylon must fall because of Israel's slain, just as the slain in all the earth have fallen because of Babylon.

docs.title: v.50
docs.text: You who have escaped the sword, leave and do not linger! Remember the LORD in a distant land, and think on Jerusalem."

docs.title: v.51
docs.text: "We are disgraced, for we have been insulted and shame covers our faces, because foreigners have entered the holy places of the LORD's house."

docs.title: v.52
docs.text: "But days are coming," declares the LORD, "when I will punish her idols, and throughout her land the wounded will groan.

docs.title: v.53
docs.text: Even if Babylon reaches the sky and fortifies her lofty stronghold, I will send destroyers against her," declares the LORD.

docs.title: v.54
docs.text: "The sound of a cry comes from Babylon, the sound of great destruction from the land of the Babylonians.

docs.title: v.55
docs.text: The LORD will destroy Babylon; he will silence her noisy din. Waves [of enemies] will rage like great waters; the roar of their voices will resound.

docs.title: v.56
docs.text: A destroyer will come against Babylon; her warriors will be captured, and their bows will be broken. For the LORD is a God of retribution; he will repay in full.

docs.title: v.57
docs.text: I will make her officials and wise men drunk, her governors, officers and warriors as well; they will sleep forever and not awake," declares the King, whose name is the LORD Almighty.

docs.title: v.58
docs.text: This is what the LORD Almighty says: "Babylon's thick wall will be leveled and her high gates set on fire; the peoples exhaust themselves for nothing, the nations' labor is only fuel for the flames."

docs.title: v.59
docs.text: This is the message Jeremiah gave to the staff officer Seraiah son of Neriah, the son of Mahseiah, when he went to Babylon with Zedekiah king of Judah in the fourth year of his reign.

docs.title: v.60
docs.text: Jeremiah had written on a scroll about all the disasters that would come upon Babylon—all that had been recorded concerning Babylon.

docs.title: v.61
docs.text: He said to Seraiah, "When you get to Babylon, see that you read all these words aloud.

docs.title: v.62
docs.text: Then say, 'O LORD, you have said you will destroy this place, so that neither man nor animal will live in it; it will be desolate forever.'

docs.title: v.63
docs.text: When you finish reading this scroll, tie a stone to it and throw it into the Euphrates.

docs.title: v.64
docs.text: Then say, 'So will Babylon sink to rise no more because of the disaster I will bring upon her. And her people will fall.'" The words of Jeremiah end here.

docs.title: v.1
docs.text: Zedekiah was twenty-one years old when he became king, and he reigned in Jerusalem eleven years. His mother's name was Hamutal daughter of Jeremiah; she was from Libnah.

docs.title: v.2
docs.text: He did evil in the eyes of the LORD, just as Jehoiakim had done.

docs.title: v.3
docs.text: It was because of the LORD's anger that all this happened to Jerusalem and Judah, and in the end he thrust them from his presence. Now Zedekiah rebelled against the king of Babylon.

docs.title: v.4
docs.text: So in the ninth year of Zedekiah's reign, on the tenth day of the tenth month, Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon marched against Jerusalem with his whole army. They camped outside the city and built siege works all around it.

docs.title: v.5
docs.text: The city was kept under siege until the eleventh year of King Zedekiah.

docs.title: v.6
docs.text: By the ninth day of the fourth month the famine in the city had become so severe that there was no food for the people to eat.

docs.title: v.7
docs.text: Then the city wall was broken through, and the whole army fled. They left the city at night through the gate between the two walls near the king's garden, though the Babylonians were surrounding the city. They fled toward the Arabah,

docs.title: v.8
docs.text: but the Babylonian army pursued King Zedekiah and overtook him in the plains of Jericho. All his soldiers were separated from him and scattered,

docs.title: v.9
docs.text: and he was captured. He was taken to the king of Babylon at Riblah in the land of Hamath, where he pronounced sentence on him.

docs.title: v.10
docs.text: There at Riblah the king of Babylon slaughtered the sons of Zedekiah before his eyes; he also killed all the officials of Judah.

docs.title: v.11
docs.text: Then he put out Zedekiah's eyes, bound him with bronze shackles and took him to Babylon, where he put him in prison till the day of his death.

docs.title: v.12
docs.text: On the tenth day of the fifth month, in the nineteenth year of Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon, Nebuzaradan commander of the imperial guard, who served the king of Babylon, came to Jerusalem.

docs.title: v.13
docs.text: He set fire to the temple of the LORD, the royal palace and all the houses of Jerusalem. Every important building he burned down.

docs.title: v.14
docs.text: The whole Babylonian army under the commander of the imperial guard broke down all the walls around Jerusalem.

docs.title: v.15
docs.text: Nebuzaradan the commander of the guard carried into exile some of the poorest people and those who remained in the city, along with the rest of the craftsmen and those who had gone over to the king of Babylon.

docs.title: v.16
docs.text: But Nebuzaradan left behind the rest of the poorest people of the land to work the vineyards and fields.

docs.title: v.17
docs.text: The Babylonians broke up the bronze pillars, the movable stands and the bronze Sea that were at the temple of the LORD and they carried all the bronze to Babylon.

docs.title: v.18
docs.text: They also took away the pots, shovels, wick trimmers, sprinkling bowls, dishes and all the bronze articles used in the temple service.

docs.title: v.19
docs.text: The commander of the imperial guard took away the basins, censers, sprinkling bowls, pots, lampstands, dishes and bowls used for drink offerings—all that were made of pure gold or silver.

docs.title: v.20
docs.text: The bronze from the two pillars, the Sea and the twelve bronze bulls under it, and the movable stands, which King Solomon had made for the temple of the LORD, was more than could be weighed.

docs.title: v.21
docs.text: Each of the pillars was eighteen cubits high and twelve cubits in circumference ; each was four fingers thick, and hollow.

docs.title: v.22
docs.text: The bronze capital on top of the one pillar was five cubits high and was decorated with a network and pomegranates of bronze all around. The other pillar, with its pomegranates, was similar.

docs.title: v.23
docs.text: There were ninety-six pomegranates on the sides; the total number of pomegranates above the surrounding network was a hundred.

docs.title: v.24
docs.text: The commander of the guard took as prisoners Seraiah the chief priest, Zephaniah the priest next in rank and the three doorkeepers.

docs.title: v.25
docs.text: Of those still in the city, he took the officer in charge of the fighting men, and seven royal advisers. He also took the secretary who was chief officer in charge of conscripting the people of the land and sixty of his men who were found in the city.

docs.title: v.26
docs.text: Nebuzaradan the commander took them all and brought them to the king of Babylon at Riblah.

docs.title: v.27
docs.text: There at Riblah, in the land of Hamath, the king had them executed. So Judah went into captivity, away from her land.

docs.title: v.28
docs.text: This is the number of the people Nebuchadnezzar carried into exile: in the seventh year, 3,023 Jews;

docs.title: v.29
docs.text: in Nebuchadnezzar's eighteenth year, 832 people from Jerusalem;

docs.title: v.30
docs.text: in his twenty-third year, 745 Jews taken into exile by Nebuzaradan the commander of the imperial guard. There were 4,600 people in all.

docs.title: v.31
docs.text: In the thirty-seventh year of the exile of Jehoiachin king of Judah, in the year Evil-Merodach became king of Babylon, he released Jehoiachin king of Judah and freed him from prison on the twenty-fifth day of the twelfth month.

docs.title: v.32
docs.text: He spoke kindly to him and gave him a seat of honor higher than those of the other kings who were with him in Babylon.

docs.title: v.33
docs.text: So Jehoiachin put aside his prison clothes and for the rest of his life ate regularly at the king's table.

docs.title: v.34
docs.text: Day by day the king of Babylon gave Jehoiachin a regular allowance as long as he lived, till the day of his death. 

docs.title: v.14
docs.text: They dress the wounds of my people as though it were not serious. 'Peace, peace,' they say, when there is no peace.

docs.title: v.16
docs.text:
This is what the Lord says: "Stand at the crossroads and look; ask for the ancient paths, ask where the good way is, and walk in it, and you will find rest for your souls. But you said, 'We will not walk in it.'

Grahm Foster introduced me to this verse when I asked him, "What advice would you give a young man who is trying to seek the Lord for direction in his life?" Look for the ancient paths. Read the stories of the saints from Hebrews 13 and learn about their lives. Seek humility rather than the path before you. How can a humble man be outside of God's will?

docs.title: v.1
docs.text: Oh that my head were a spring of water and my eyes a fountain of tears! I would weep day and night for the slain of my people.

docs.title: v.23
docs.text: "Let not the wise man boast of his wisdom or the strong man boast of his strength or the rich man boast of his riches,

docs.title: v.24
docs.text:
but let him who boasts boast about this: that he understands and knows me, that I am the Lord, who exercises kindness, justice and righteousness on earth, for in these I delight," declares the Lord.

The knowledge of God relates to three leading attributes, the combination of which is very instructive. First, loving-kindness. This is not to be understood in a vague and general sense of the love of God to all mankind; the term has a special connotation with regard to the Israelitish people. God shows loving-kindness to those with whom he is in covenant; hence the combination "loving-kindness and faithfulness" (Psalm 85:10, corrected version), and as here (comp. Psalm 5:7, 8; Psalm 36:5, 6), "mercy and righteousness." Israel is weak and erring, and needs mercies of all sorts, which Jehovah, in his "loving-kindness," vouchsafes. Next, judgment, or justice. Jehovah is a King, helps the poor and weak to their right, and punishes the wrong-doer (comp. Jeremiah 21:12). Then, righteousness - a similar but wider term. This is the quality which leads its subject to adhere to a fixed rule of conduct. God's rule is his covenant; hence "righteousness" shows itself in all such acts as tend to the full realizing of the covenant with Israel, including the "plan of salvation." It is by no means to be confined to exacting penalties and conferring rewards.

docs.title: Overview:
docs.text:
Job in Hebrew → persecuted, he that weeps, cries out of a hollow place, one who turns to God. Theme: Suffering Key Scriptures: 2:3, 13:15

Chapters 1-2: Prologue Chapters 3-27: Consolation and Accusation from Bad Friends Chapter 28: Interlude Hymn Chapters 29-42: Discussion of God's Ways Chapters 38-41: God Answers Chapter 42: Epilogue - Job's Summary

Purposes: 1. To show the problem of how suffering can be reconciled with the justice of God (Theodicy). 2. To show Job as God's example of patience under suffering.

Messages: 1. Bad things happen to good people. 2. There is always a reason why bad things happen to good people. 3. Suffering can be used to bring us closer to God, both personally (in character) and relationally (in our knowledge of Him). 4. God permits evil to act within the boundaries he sovereignly sets.

docs.title: v.1
docs.text: In the land of Uz there lived a man whose name was Job. This man was blameless and upright; he feared God and shunned evil.

docs.title: v.2
docs.text: He had seven sons and three daughters,

docs.title: v.3
docs.text: and he owned seven thousand sheep, three thousand camels, five hundred yoke of oxen and five hundred donkeys, and had a large number of servants. He was the greatest man among all the people of the East.

docs.title: v.4
docs.text: His sons used to take turns holding feasts in their homes, and they would invite their three sisters to eat and drink with them.

docs.title: v.5
docs.text: When a period of feasting had run its course, Job would send and have them purified. Early in the morning he would sacrifice a burnt offering for each of them, thinking, "Perhaps my children have sinned and cursed God in their hearts." This was Job's regular custom.

docs.title: v.6
docs.text: One day the angels  came to present themselves before the LORD, and Satan also came with them.

docs.title: v.7
docs.text: The LORD said to Satan, "Where have you come from?" Satan answered the LORD, "From roaming through the earth and going back and forth in it."

docs.title: v.8
docs.text:
Then the LORD said to Satan, "Have you considered my servant Job? There is no one on earth like him; he is blameless and upright, a man who fears God and shuns evil."

In spite of all these high accolades for Job, he knew that he was a sinner, for he queried, "How can mortal be righteous before God?" (Job 9:2). He further acknowledged his sin (Job 10:6; 14:16-17). Accordingly, the use of the word blameless or perfect does not imply that one has attained perfection or a state in which one no longer sins. Even the creature in Eden (probably Lucifer) that was created "perfect" was found to be capable of sin (Ezek 28:13-15).

docs.title: v.9
docs.text: "Does Job fear God for nothing?" Satan replied.

docs.title: v.10
docs.text: "Have you not put a hedge around him and his household and everything he has? You have blessed the work of his hands, so that his flocks and herds are spread throughout the land.

docs.title: v.11
docs.text: But stretch out your hand and strike everything he has, and he will surely curse you to your face."

docs.title: v.12
docs.text: The LORD said to Satan, "Very well, then, everything he has is in your hands, but on the man himself do not lay a finger." Then Satan went out from the presence of the LORD.

docs.title: v.13
docs.text: One day when Job's sons and daughters were feasting and drinking wine at the oldest brother's house,

docs.title: v.14
docs.text: a messenger came to Job and said, "The oxen were plowing and the donkeys were grazing nearby,

docs.title: v.15
docs.text: and the Sabeans attacked and carried them off. They put the servants to the sword, and I am the only one who has escaped to tell you!"

docs.title: v.16
docs.text: While he was still speaking, another messenger came and said, "The fire of God fell from the sky and burned up the sheep and the servants, and I am the only one who has escaped to tell you!"

docs.title: v.17
docs.text: While he was still speaking, another messenger came and said, "The Chaldeans formed three raiding parties and swept down on your camels and carried them off. They put the servants to the sword, and I am the only one who has escaped to tell you!"

docs.title: v.18
docs.text: While he was still speaking, yet another messenger came and said, "Your sons and daughters were feasting and drinking wine at the oldest brother's house,

docs.title: v.19
docs.text: when suddenly a mighty wind swept in from the desert and struck the four corners of the house. It collapsed on them and they are dead, and I am the only one who has escaped to tell you!"

docs.title: v.20
docs.text: At this, Job got up and tore his robe and shaved his head. Then he fell to the ground in worship

docs.title: v.21
docs.text: and said: "Naked I came from my mother's womb, and naked I will depart. The LORD gave and the LORD has taken away; may the name of the LORD be praised."

docs.title: v.22
docs.text: In all this, Job did not sin by charging God with wrongdoing.

docs.title: v.1
docs.text: "I loathe my very life; therefore I will give free rein to my complaint and speak out in the bitterness of my soul.

docs.title: v.2
docs.text: I will say to God: Do not condemn me, but tell me what charges you have against me.

docs.title: v.3
docs.text: Does it please you to oppress me, to spurn the work of your hands, while you smile on the schemes of the wicked?

docs.title: v.4
docs.text: Do you have eyes of flesh? Do you see as a mortal sees?

docs.title: v.5
docs.text: Are your days like those of a mortal or your years like those of a man,

docs.title: v.6
docs.text: that you must search out my faults and probe after my sin--

docs.title: v.7
docs.text: though you know that I am not guilty and that no one can rescue me from your hand?

docs.title: v.8
docs.text: "Your hands shaped me and made me. Will you now turn and destroy me?

docs.title: v.9
docs.text: Remember that you molded me like clay. Will you now turn me to dust again?

docs.title: v.10
docs.text: Did you not pour me out like milk and curdle me like cheese,

docs.title: v.11
docs.text: clothe me with skin and flesh and knit me together with bones and sinews?

docs.title: v.12
docs.text: You gave me life and showed me kindness, and in your providence watched over my spirit.

docs.title: v.13
docs.text: "But this is what you concealed in your heart, and I know that this was in your mind:

docs.title: v.14
docs.text: If I sinned, you would be watching me and would not let my offense go unpunished.

docs.title: v.15
docs.text: If I am guilty--woe to me! Even if I am innocent, I cannot lift my head, for I am full of shame and drowned in my affliction.

docs.title: v.16
docs.text: If I hold my head high, you stalk me like a lion and again display your awesome power against me.

docs.title: v.17
docs.text: You bring new witnesses against me and increase your anger toward me; your forces come against me wave upon wave.

docs.title: v.18
docs.text: "Why then did you bring me out of the womb? I wish I had died before any eye saw me.

docs.title: v.19
docs.text: If only I had never come into being, or had been carried straight from the womb to the grave!

docs.title: v.20
docs.text: Are not my few days almost over? Turn away from me so I can have a moment's joy

docs.title: v.21
docs.text: before I go to the place of no return, to the land of gloom and deep shadow,

docs.title: v.22
docs.text: to the land of deepest night, of deep shadow and disorder, where even the light is like darkness."

docs.title: v.10
docs.text: In his hand is the life of every creature and the breath of all mankind.

docs.title: v.1
docs.text: "My eyes have seen all this, my ears have heard and understood it.

docs.title: v.2
docs.text: What you know, I also know; I am not inferior to you.

docs.title: v.3
docs.text: But I desire to speak to the Almighty and to argue my case with God.

docs.title: v.4
docs.text: You, however, smear me with lies; you are worthless physicians, all of you!

docs.title: v.5
docs.text: If only you would be altogether silent! For you, that would be wisdom.

docs.title: v.6
docs.text: Hear now my argument; listen to the plea of my lips.

docs.title: v.7
docs.text: Will you speak wickedly on God's behalf? Will you speak deceitfully for him?

docs.title: v.8
docs.text: Will you show him partiality? Will you argue the case for God?

docs.title: v.9
docs.text: Would it turn out well if he examined you? Could you deceive him as you might deceive men?

docs.title: v.10
docs.text: He would surely rebuke you if you secretly showed partiality.

docs.title: v.11
docs.text: Would not his splendor terrify you? Would not the dread of him fall on you?

docs.title: v.12
docs.text: Your maxims are proverbs of ashes; your defenses are defenses of clay.

docs.title: v.13
docs.text: "Keep silent and let me speak; then let come to me what may.

docs.title: v.14
docs.text: Why do I put myself in jeopardy and take my life in my hands?

docs.title: v.15
docs.text: ===Though he slay me, yet will I hope in him; I will surely defend my ways to his face.===

docs.title: v.16
docs.text: Indeed, this will turn out for my deliverance, for no godless man would dare come before him!

docs.title: v.17
docs.text: Listen carefully to my words; let your ears take in what I say.

docs.title: v.18
docs.text: Now that I have prepared my case, I know I will be vindicated.

docs.title: v.19
docs.text: Can anyone bring charges against me? If so, I will be silent and die.

docs.title: v.20
docs.text: "Only grant me these two things, O God, and then I will not hide from you:

docs.title: v.21
docs.text: Withdraw your hand far from me, and stop frightening me with your terrors.

docs.title: v.22
docs.text: Then summon me and I will answer, or let me speak, and you reply.

docs.title: v.23
docs.text: How many wrongs and sins have I committed? Show me my offense and my sin.

docs.title: v.24
docs.text: Why do you hide your face and consider me your enemy?

docs.title: v.25
docs.text: Will you torment a windblown leaf? Will you chase after dry chaff?

docs.title: v.26
docs.text: For you write down bitter things against me and make me inherit the sins of my youth.

docs.title: v.27
docs.text: You fasten my feet in shackles; you keep close watch on all my paths by putting marks on the soles of my feet.

docs.title: v.28
docs.text: "So man wastes away like something rotten, like a garment eaten by moths.

docs.title: v.1
docs.text: "Man born of woman is of few days and full of trouble.

docs.title: v.2
docs.text: He springs up like a flower and withers away; like a fleeting shadow, he does not endure.

docs.title: v.3
docs.text: Do you fix your eye on such a one? Will you bring him before you for judgment?

docs.title: v.4
docs.text: Who can bring what is pure from the impure? No one!

docs.title: v.5
docs.text: Man's days are determined; you have decreed the number of his months and have set limits he cannot exceed.

docs.title: v.6
docs.text: So look away from him and let him alone, till he has put in his time like a hired man.

docs.title: v.7
docs.text: "At least there is hope for a tree: If it is cut down, it will sprout again, and its new shoots will not fail.

docs.title: v.8
docs.text: Its roots may grow old in the ground and its stump die in the soil,

docs.title: v.9
docs.text: yet at the scent of water it will bud and put forth shoots like a plant.

docs.title: v.10
docs.text: But man dies and is laid low; he breathes his last and is no more.

docs.title: v.11
docs.text: As water disappears from the sea or a riverbed becomes parched and dry,

docs.title: v.12
docs.text: so man lies down and does not rise; till the heavens are no more, men will not awake or be roused from their sleep.

docs.title: v.13
docs.text: "If only you would hide me in the grave and conceal me till your anger has passed! If only you would set me a time and then remember me!

docs.title: v.14
docs.text: If a man dies, will he live again? All the days of my hard service I will wait for my renewal to come.

docs.title: v.15
docs.text: You will call and I will answer you; you will long for the creature your hands have made.

docs.title: v.16-17
docs.text: Surely then you will count my steps but not keep track of my sin.17My offenses will be sealed up in a bag; you will cover over my sin.

docs.title: v.18
docs.text: "But as a mountain erodes and crumbles and as a rock is moved from its place,

docs.title: v.19
docs.text: as water wears away stones and torrents wash away the soil, so you destroy man's hope.

docs.title: v.20
docs.text: You overpower him once for all, and he is gone; you change his countenance and send him away.

docs.title: v.21
docs.text: If his sons are honored, he does not know it; if they are brought low, he does not see it.

docs.title: v.22
docs.text: He feels but the pain of his own body and mourns only for himself."

docs.title: v.1
docs.text: On another day the angels came to present themselves before the LORD, and Satan also came with them to present himself before him.

docs.title: v.2
docs.text: And the LORD said to Satan, "Where have you come from?" Satan answered the LORD, "From roaming through the earth and going back and forth in it."

docs.title: v.3
docs.text: Then the LORD said to Satan, "Have you considered my servant Job? There is no one on earth like him; he is blameless and upright, a man who fears God and shuns evil. And he still maintains his integrity, though you incited me against him to ruin him without any reason."

docs.title: v.4
docs.text: "Skin for skin!" Satan replied. "A man will give all he has for his own life.

docs.title: v.5
docs.text: But stretch out your hand and strike his flesh and bones, and he will surely curse you to your face."

docs.title: v.6
docs.text: The LORD said to Satan, "Very well, then, he is in your hands; but you must spare his life."

docs.title: v.7
docs.text: So Satan went out from the presence of the LORD and afflicted Job with painful sores from the soles of his feet to the top of his head.

docs.title: v.8
docs.text: Then Job took a piece of broken pottery and scraped himself with it as he sat among the ashes.

docs.title: v.9
docs.text: His wife said to him, "Are you still holding on to your integrity? Curse God and die!"

docs.title: v.10
docs.text: He replied, "You are talking like a foolish woman. Shall we accept good from God, and not trouble?" In all this, Job did not sin in what he said.

docs.title: v.11
docs.text: When Job's three friends, Eliphaz the Temanite, Bildad the Shuhite and Zophar the Naamathite, heard about all the troubles that had come upon him, they set out from their homes and met together by agreement to go and sympathize with him and comfort him.

docs.title: v.12
docs.text: When they saw him from a distance, they could hardly recognize him; they began to weep aloud, and they tore their robes and sprinkled dust on their heads.

docs.title: v.13
docs.text: Then they sat on the ground with him for seven days and seven nights. No one said a word to him, because they saw how great his suffering was.

docs.title: v.1
docs.text: Then Job replied:

docs.title: v.2
docs.text: "How you have helped the powerless! How you have saved the arm that is feeble!

docs.title: v.3
docs.text: What advice you have offered to one without wisdom! And what great insight you have displayed!

docs.title: v.4
docs.text: Who has helped you utter these words? And whose spirit spoke from your mouth?

docs.title: v.5
docs.text: "The dead are in deep anguish, those beneath the waters and all that live in them.

docs.title: v.6
docs.text: Death is naked before God; Destruction lies uncovered.

docs.title: v.7
docs.text: He spreads out the northern [skies] over empty space; he suspends the earth over nothing.

docs.title: v.8
docs.text: He wraps up the waters in his clouds, yet the clouds do not burst under their weight.

docs.title: v.9
docs.text: He covers the face of the full moon, spreading his clouds over it.

docs.title: v.10
docs.text: He marks out the horizon on the face of the waters for a boundary between light and darkness.

docs.title: v.11
docs.text: The pillars of the heavens quake, aghast at his rebuke.

docs.title: v.12-13
docs.text: By his power he churned up the sea; by his wisdom he cut Rahab to pieces. 13By his breath the skies became fair; his hand pierced the gliding serpent.

docs.title: v.14
docs.text: And these are but the outer fringe of his works; how faint the whisper we hear of him! Who then can understand the thunder of his power?"

docs.title: v.1-2
docs.text: "There is a mine for silver and a place where gold is refined. 2Iron is taken from the earth, and copper is smelted from ore.

docs.title: v.3-4
docs.text: Man puts an end to the darkness; he searches the farthest recesses for ore in the blackest darkness. 4Far from where people dwell he cuts a shaft, in places forgotten by the foot of man; far from men he dangles and sways.

docs.title: v.12
docs.text: "But where can wisdom be found? Where does understanding dwell?

docs.title: v.13
docs.text: Man does not comprehend its worth; it cannot be found in the land of the living.

docs.title: v.18
docs.text: Coral and jasper are not worthy of mention; the price of wisdom is beyond rubies.

docs.title: v.33-35
docs.text:
If only there were someone to arbitrate between us, to lay his hand upon us both, 34someone to remove God's rod from me, so that his terror would frighten me no more. 35Then I would speak up without fear of him, but as it now stands with me, I cannot.

In v.33 Job touched on the mystery through which God would eventually provide godliness for man. He yearned for a mediator ("someone to arbitrate"; GK 3519) between himself and God. Such a person would not have to be one who stands over both God and Job in order to judge between them. As "one who argues a case," he is a negotiator who is able to bring parties together. We should not infer from this that the book of Job here is directly predictive of the NT doctrine of Christ as mediator. For one thing Job was not looking for a mediator to forgive him of his sins so that he might be received by God; Job was yearning for a mediator who could prove that he was innocent and could somehow be effective with God despite his infinite power and wisdom. But having said that, we have here a rudimentary idea that is certainly evocative of that NT concept. This idea will move on to greater ramifications in 16:20-21 and 19:25-26.

docs.title: v.3
docs.text:
They cast lots for my people and traded boys for prostitutes; they sold girls for wine that they might drink.

It was customary with conquerors, in those days, to divide the captives, taken in war, among themselves by lot, and so did these enemies of the Jews. These instances are mentioned, to signify the contempt in which these enemies of the Jews held the worshippers of the true God; they parted with them, when they had taken them captives, upon the vilest terms, as setting little or no value upon them. In Mingrelia, according to Sir John Chardin, they sell captive children for provisions and for wine: see Harmer vol. 2. p. 374.

docs.text: So on the second day they marched around the city once and returned to the camp. They did this for six days.

docs.title: v.15
docs.text: On the seventh day, they got up at daybreak and marched around the city seven times in the same manner, except that on that day they circled the city seven times.

docs.title: v.16
docs.text: The seventh time around, when the priests sounded the trumpet blast, Joshua commanded the people, "Shout! For the LORD has given you the city!

docs.title: v.17
docs.text: The city and all that is in it are to be devoted to the LORD. Only Rahab the prostitute and all who are with her in her house shall be spared, because she hid the spies we sent.

docs.title: v.18
docs.text: But keep away from the devoted things, so that you will not bring about your own destruction by taking any of them. Otherwise you will make the camp of Israel liable to destruction and bring trouble on it.

docs.title: v.19
docs.text: All the silver and gold and the articles of bronze and iron are sacred to the LORD and must go into his treasury."

docs.title: v.20
docs.text: When the trumpets sounded, the people shouted, and at the sound of the trumpet, when the people gave a loud shout, the wall collapsed; so every man charged straight in, and they took the city.

docs.title: v.21
docs.text: They devoted the city to the LORD and destroyed with the sword every living thing in it—men and women, young and old, cattle, sheep and donkeys.

docs.title: v.22
docs.text: Joshua said to the two men who had spied out the land, "Go into the prostitute's house and bring her out and all who belong to her, in accordance with your oath to her."

docs.title: v.23
docs.text: So the young men who had done the spying went in and brought out Rahab, her father and mother and brothers and all who belonged to her. They brought out her entire family and put them in a place outside the camp of Israel.

docs.title: v.24
docs.text: Then they burned the whole city and everything in it, but they put the silver and gold and the articles of bronze and iron into the treasury of the LORD's house.

docs.title: v.25
docs.text: But Joshua spared Rahab the prostitute, with her family and all who belonged to her, because she hid the men Joshua had sent as spies to Jericho—and she lives among the Israelites to this day.

docs.title: v.26
docs.text: At that time Joshua pronounced this solemn oath: "Cursed before the LORD is the man who undertakes to rebuild this city, Jericho: "At the cost of his firstborn son will he lay its foundations; at the cost of his youngest will he set up its gates."

docs.title: v.27
docs.text: So the LORD was with Joshua, and his fame spread throughout the land.

docs.title: v.1
docs.text: Now when all the kings west of the Jordan heard about these things—those in the hill country, in the western foothills, and along the entire coast of the Great Sea as far as Lebanon (the kings of the Hittites, Amorites, Canaanites, Perizzites, Hivites and Jebusites)—

docs.title: v.2
docs.text: they came together to make war against Joshua and Israel.

docs.title: v.3
docs.text: However, when the people of Gibeon heard what Joshua had done to Jericho and Ai,

docs.title: v.4
docs.text: they resorted to a ruse: They went as a delegation whose donkeys were loaded with worn-out sacks and old wineskins, cracked and mended.

docs.title: v.5
docs.text: The men put worn and patched sandals on their feet and wore old clothes. All the bread of their food supply was dry and moldy.

docs.title: v.6
docs.text: Then they went to Joshua in the camp at Gilgal and said to him and the men of Israel, "We have come from a distant country; make a treaty with us."

docs.title: v.7
docs.text: The men of Israel said to the Hivites, "But perhaps you live near us. How then can we make a treaty with you?"

docs.title: v.8
docs.text: "We are your servants," they said to Joshua. But Joshua asked, "Who are you and where do you come from?"

docs.title: v.9
docs.text: They answered: "Your servants have come from a very distant country because of the fame of the LORD your God. For we have heard reports of him: all that he did in Egypt,

docs.title: v.10
docs.text: and all that he did to the two kings of the Amorites east of the Jordan—Sihon king of Heshbon, and Og king of Bashan, who reigned in Ashtaroth.

docs.title: v.11
docs.text: And our elders and all those living in our country said to us, 'Take provisions for your journey; go and meet them and say to them, "We are your servants; make a treaty with us."'

docs.title: v.12
docs.text: This bread of ours was warm when we packed it at home on the day we left to come to you. But now see how dry and moldy it is.

docs.title: v.13
docs.text: And these wineskins that we filled were new, but see how cracked they are. And our clothes and sandals are worn out by the very long journey."

docs.title: v.14
docs.text: The men of Israel sampled their provisions but did not inquire of the LORD.

docs.title: v.15
docs.text: Then Joshua made a treaty of peace with them to let them live, and the leaders of the assembly ratified it by oath.

docs.title: v.16
docs.text: Three days after they made the treaty with the Gibeonites, the Israelites heard that they were neighbors, living near them.

docs.title: v.17
docs.text: So the Israelites set out and on the third day came to their cities: Gibeon, Kephirah, Beeroth and Kiriath Jearim.

docs.title: v.18
docs.text: But the Israelites did not attack them, because the leaders of the assembly had sworn an oath to them by the LORD, the God of Israel. The whole assembly grumbled against the leaders,

docs.title: v.19
docs.text: but all the leaders answered, "We have given them our oath by the LORD, the God of Israel, and we cannot touch them now.

docs.title: v.20
docs.text: This is what we will do to them: We will let them live, so that wrath will not fall on us for breaking the oath we swore to them."

docs.title: v.21
docs.text: They continued, "Let them live, but let them be woodcutters and water carriers for the entire community." So the leaders' promise to them was kept.

docs.title: v.22
docs.text: Then Joshua summoned the Gibeonites and said, "Why did you deceive us by saying, 'We live a long way from you,' while actually you live near us?

docs.title: v.23
docs.text: You are now under a curse: You will never cease to serve as woodcutters and water carriers for the house of my God."

docs.title: v.24
docs.text: They answered Joshua, "Your servants were clearly told how the LORD your God had commanded his servant Moses to give you the whole land and to wipe out all its inhabitants from before you. So we feared for our lives because of you, and that is why we did this.

docs.title: v.25
docs.text: We are now in your hands. Do to us whatever seems good and right to you."

docs.title: v.26
docs.text: So Joshua saved them from the Israelites, and they did not kill them.

docs.title: v.27
docs.text: That day he made the Gibeonites woodcutters and water carriers for the community and for the altar of the LORD at the place the LORD would choose. And that is what they are to this day.

docs.title: Overview:
docs.text:
judges → deliverer or savior; leadership Theme: Failure Through Compromise

Key Scriptures: 2:10; 21:25

Chapters 1-2: The consequences of Compromise (failure to completely drive out Canaanites; national unfaithfulness to God) Chapters 3-16: God raises up judges (Gideon, Deborah, etc.) Chapters 17-21: Israel devolves into political corruption and chaos

Purposes: 1. To show how Israel drifted away from God 2. To show how Israel was punished for compromise 3. To show how Israel went into cycles of sin because of compromise

Messages: 1. The effect of Original Sin is that we have a tendency to wander 2. When we free ourselves from God we enslaves ourselves to sin 1. Freedom from God is slavery. 3. God is always faithful and makes a way for salvation

docs.title: v.1
docs.text: After the death of Joshua, the Israelites asked the LORD, "Who will be the first to go up and fight for us against the Canaanites?"

docs.title: v.2
docs.text: The LORD answered, "Judah is to go; I have given the land into their hands."

docs.title: v.3
docs.text: Then the men of Judah said to the Simeonites their brothers, "Come up with us into the territory allotted to us, to fight against the Canaanites. We in turn will go with you into yours." So the Simeonites went with them.

docs.title: v.4
docs.text: When Judah attacked, the LORD gave the Canaanites and Perizzites into their hands and they struck down ten thousand men at Bezek.

docs.title: v.5
docs.text: It was there that they found Adoni-Bezek and fought against him, putting to rout the Canaanites and Perizzites.

docs.title: v.6
docs.text: Adoni-Bezek fled, but they chased him and caught him, and cut off his thumbs and big toes.

docs.title: v.7
docs.text: Then Adoni-Bezek said, "Seventy kings with their thumbs and big toes cut off have picked up scraps under my table. Now God has paid me back for what I did to them." They brought him to Jerusalem, and he died there.

docs.title: v.8
docs.text: The men of Judah attacked Jerusalem also and took it. They put the city to the sword and set it on fire.

docs.title: v.9
docs.text: After that, the men of Judah went down to fight against the Canaanites living in the hill country, the Negev and the western foothills.

docs.title: v.10
docs.text: They advanced against the Canaanites living in Hebron (formerly called Kiriath Arba) and defeated Sheshai, Ahiman and Talmai.

docs.title: v.11
docs.text: From there they advanced against the people living in Debir (formerly called Kiriath Sepher).

docs.title: v.12
docs.text: And Caleb said, "I will give my daughter Acsah in marriage to the man who attacks and captures Kiriath Sepher."

docs.title: v.13
docs.text: Othniel son of Kenaz, Caleb's younger brother, took it; so Caleb gave his daughter Acsah to him in marriage.

docs.title: v.14
docs.text: One day when she came to Othniel, she urged him to ask her father for a field. When she got off her donkey, Caleb asked her, "What can I do for you?"

docs.title: v.15
docs.text: She replied, "Do me a special favor. Since you have given me land in the Negev, give me also springs of water." Then Caleb gave her the upper and lower springs.

docs.title: v.16
docs.text: The descendants of Moses' father-in-law, the Kenite, went up from the City of Palms with the men of Judah to live among the people of the Desert of Judah in the Negev near Arad.

docs.title: v.17
docs.text: Then the men of Judah went with the Simeonites their brothers and attacked the Canaanites living in Zephath, and they totally destroyed the city. Therefore it was called Hormah.

docs.title: v.18
docs.text: The men of Judah also took Gaza, Ashkelon and Ekron—each city with its territory.

docs.title: v.19
docs.text: The LORD was with the men of Judah. They took possession of the hill country, but they were unable to drive the people from the plains, because they had iron chariots.

docs.title: v.20
docs.text: As Moses had promised, Hebron was given to Caleb, who drove from it the three sons of Anak.

docs.title: v.21
docs.text: The Benjamites, however, failed to dislodge the Jebusites, who were living in Jerusalem; to this day the Jebusites live there with the Benjamites.

docs.title: v.22
docs.text: Now the house of Joseph attacked Bethel, and the LORD was with them.

docs.title: v.23
docs.text: When they sent men to spy out Bethel (formerly called Luz),

docs.title: v.24
docs.text: the spies saw a man coming out of the city and they said to him, "Show us how to get into the city and we will see that you are treated well."

docs.title: v.25
docs.text: So he showed them, and they put the city to the sword but spared the man and his whole family.

docs.title: v.26
docs.text: He then went to the land of the Hittites, where he built a city and called it Luz, which is its name to this day.

docs.title: v.27
docs.text: But Manasseh did not drive out the people of Beth Shan or Taanach or Dor or Ibleam or Megiddo and their surrounding settlements, for the Canaanites were determined to live in that land.

docs.title: v.28
docs.text: When Israel became strong, they pressed the Canaanites into forced labor but never drove them out completely.

docs.title: v.29
docs.text: Nor did Ephraim drive out the Canaanites living in Gezer, but the Canaanites continued to live there among them.

docs.title: v.30
docs.text: Neither did Zebulun drive out the Canaanites living in Kitron or Nahalol, who remained among them; but they did subject them to forced labor.

docs.title: v.31
docs.text: Nor did Asher drive out those living in Acco or Sidon or Ahlab or Aczib or Helbah or Aphek or Rehob,

docs.title: v.32
docs.text: and because of this the people of Asher lived among the Canaanite inhabitants of the land.

docs.title: v.33
docs.text: Neither did Naphtali drive out those living in Beth Shemesh or Beth Anath; but the Naphtalites too lived among the Canaanite inhabitants of the land, and those living in Beth Shemesh and Beth Anath became forced laborers for them.

docs.title: v.34
docs.text: The Amorites confined the Danites to the hill country, not allowing them to come down into the plain.

docs.title: v.35
docs.text: And the Amorites were determined also to hold out in Mount Heres, Aijalon and Shaalbim, but when the power of the house of Joseph increased, they too were pressed into forced labor.

docs.title: v.36
docs.text: The boundary of the Amorites was from Scorpion Pass to Sela and beyond.

docs.title: v.15-16
docs.text:
But the Israelites said to the LORD, "We have sinned. Do with us whatever you think best, but please rescue us now." 16 Then they got rid of the foreign gods among them and served the LORD. And he could bear Israel's misery no longer.

A genuine cry for mercy liberates us from expectation of how God shall deal with our sins. We appeal to His eternal characteristics of lovingkindness towards humanity—not His outward pattern of redemption.

docs.title: v.10
docs.text: After that whole generation had been gathered to their fathers, another generation grew up, who knew neither the LORD nor what he had done for Israel.

docs.title: v.25
docs.text: In those days Israel had no king; everyone did as they saw fit.

docs.title: v.1
docs.text: These are the nations the LORD left to test all those Israelites who had not experienced any of the wars in Canaan

docs.title: v.2
docs.text: (he did this only to teach warfare to the descendants of the Israelites who had not had previous battle experience):

docs.title: v.3
docs.text: the five rulers of the Philistines, all the Canaanites, the Sidonians, and the Hivites living in the Lebanon mountains from Mount Baal Hermon to Lebo Hamath.

docs.title: v.4
docs.text: They were left to test the Israelites to see whether they would obey the LORD's commands, which he had given their forefathers through Moses.

docs.title: v.5
docs.text: The Israelites lived among the Canaanites, Hittites, Amorites, Perizzites, Hivites and Jebusites.

docs.title: v.6
docs.text: They took their daughters in marriage and gave their own daughters to their sons, and served their gods.

docs.title: v.7
docs.text: The Israelites did evil in the eyes of the LORD; they forgot the LORD their God and served the Baals and the Asherahs.

docs.title: v.8
docs.text: The anger of the LORD burned against Israel so that he sold them into the hands of Cushan-Rishathaim king of Aram Naharaim, to whom the Israelites were subject for eight years.

docs.title: v.9
docs.text: But when they cried out to the LORD, he raised up for them a deliverer, Othniel son of Kenaz, Caleb's younger brother, who saved them.

docs.title: v.10
docs.text: The Spirit of the LORD came upon him, so that he became Israel's judge and went to war. The LORD gave Cushan-Rishathaim king of Aram into the hands of Othniel, who overpowered him.

docs.title: v.11
docs.text: So the land had peace for forty years, until Othniel son of Kenaz died.

docs.title: v.12
docs.text: Once again the Israelites did evil in the eyes of the LORD, and because they did this evil the LORD gave Eglon king of Moab power over Israel.

docs.title: v.13
docs.text: Getting the Ammonites and Amalekites to join him, Eglon came and attacked Israel, and they took possession of the City of Palms.

docs.title: v.14
docs.text: The Israelites were subject to Eglon king of Moab for eighteen years.

docs.title: v.15
docs.text: Again the Israelites cried out to the LORD, and he gave them a deliverer—Ehud, a left-handed man, the son of Gera the Benjamite. The Israelites sent him with tribute to Eglon king of Moab.

docs.title: v.16
docs.text: Now Ehud had made a double-edged sword about a foot and a half long, which he strapped to his right thigh under his clothing.

docs.title: v.17
docs.text: He presented the tribute to Eglon king of Moab, who was a very fat man.

docs.title: v.18
docs.text: After Ehud had presented the tribute, he sent on their way the men who had carried it.

docs.title: v.19
docs.text: At the idols near Gilgal he himself turned back and said, "I have a secret message for you, O king." The king said, "Quiet!" And all his attendants left him.

docs.title: v.20
docs.text: Ehud then approached him while he was sitting alone in the upper room of his summer palace and said, "I have a message from God for you." As the king rose from his seat,

docs.title: v.21
docs.text: Ehud reached with his left hand, drew the sword from his right thigh and plunged it into the king's belly.

docs.title: v.22
docs.text: Even the handle sank in after the blade, which came out his back. Ehud did not pull the sword out, and the fat closed in over it.

docs.title: v.23
docs.text: Then Ehud went out to the porch ; he shut the doors of the upper room behind him and locked them.

docs.title: v.24
docs.text: After he had gone, the servants came and found the doors of the upper room locked. They said, "He must be relieving himself in the inner room of the house."

docs.title: v.25
docs.text: They waited to the point of embarrassment, but when he did not open the doors of the room, they took a key and unlocked them. There they saw their lord fallen to the floor, dead.

docs.title: v.26
docs.text: While they waited, Ehud got away. He passed by the idols and escaped to Seirah.

docs.title: v.27
docs.text: When he arrived there, he blew a trumpet in the hill country of Ephraim, and the Israelites went down with him from the hills, with him leading them.

docs.title: v.28
docs.text: "Follow me," he ordered, "for the LORD has given Moab, your enemy, into your hands." So they followed him down and, taking possession of the fords of the Jordan that led to Moab, they allowed no one to cross over.

docs.title: v.29
docs.text: At that time they struck down about ten thousand Moabites, all vigorous and strong; not a man escaped.

docs.title: v.30
docs.text: That day Moab was made subject to Israel, and the land had peace for eighty years.

docs.title: v.31
docs.text: After Ehud came Shamgar son of Anath, who struck down six hundred Philistines with an oxgoad. He too saved Israel.

docs.title: v.1
docs.text: Abimelech son of Jerub-Baal went to his mother's brothers in Shechem and said to them and to all his mother's clan,

docs.title: v.2
docs.text: "Ask all the citizens of Shechem, 'Which is better for you: to have all seventy of Jerub-Baal's sons rule over you, or just one man?' Remember, I am your flesh and blood."

docs.title: v.3
docs.text: When the brothers repeated all this to the citizens of Shechem, they were inclined to follow Abimelech, for they said, "He is our brother."

docs.title: v.4
docs.text: They gave him seventy shekels of silver from the temple of Baal-Berith, and Abimelech used it to hire reckless adventurers, who became his followers.

docs.title: v.5
docs.text: He went to his father's home in Ophrah and on one stone murdered his seventy brothers, the sons of Jerub-Baal. But Jotham, the youngest son of Jerub-Baal, escaped by hiding.

docs.title: v.6
docs.text: Then all the citizens of Shechem and Beth Millo gathered beside the great tree at the pillar in Shechem to crown Abimelech king.

docs.title: v.7
docs.text: When Jotham was told about this, he climbed up on the top of Mount Gerizim and shouted to them, "Listen to me, citizens of Shechem, so that God may listen to you.

docs.title: v.8
docs.text: One day the trees went out to anoint a king for themselves. They said to the olive tree, 'Be our king.'

docs.title: v.9
docs.text: "But the olive tree answered, 'Should I give up my oil, by which both gods and men are honored, to hold sway over the trees?'

docs.title: v.10
docs.text: "Next, the trees said to the fig tree, 'Come and be our king.'

docs.title: v.11
docs.text: "But the fig tree replied, 'Should I give up my fruit, so good and sweet, to hold sway over the trees?'

docs.title: v.12
docs.text: "Then the trees said to the vine, 'Come and be our king.'

docs.title: v.13
docs.text: "But the vine answered, 'Should I give up my wine, which cheers both gods and men, to hold sway over the trees?'

docs.title: v.14
docs.text: "Finally all the trees said to the thornbush, 'Come and be our king.'

docs.title: v.15
docs.text: "The thornbush said to the trees, 'If you really want to anoint me king over you, come and take refuge in my shade; but if not, then let fire come out of the thornbush and consume the cedars of Lebanon!'

docs.title: v.16
docs.text: "Now if you have acted honorably and in good faith when you made Abimelech king, and if you have been fair to Jerub-Baal and his family, and if you have treated him as he deserves—

docs.title: v.17
docs.text: and to think that my father fought for you, risked his life to rescue you from the hand of Midian

docs.title: v.18
docs.text: (but today you have revolted against my father's family, murdered his seventy sons on a single stone, and made Abimelech, the son of his slave girl, king over the citizens of Shechem because he is your brother)—

docs.title: v.19
docs.text: if then you have acted honorably and in good faith toward Jerub-Baal and his family today, may Abimelech be your joy, and may you be his, too!

docs.title: v.20
docs.text: But if you have not, let fire come out from Abimelech and consume you, citizens of Shechem and Beth Millo, and let fire come out from you, citizens of Shechem and Beth Millo, and consume Abimelech!"

docs.title: v.21
docs.text: Then Jotham fled, escaping to Beer, and he lived there because he was afraid of his brother Abimelech.

docs.title: v.22
docs.text: After Abimelech had governed Israel three years,

docs.title: v.23
docs.text:
God sent an evil spirit between Abimelech and the citizens of Shechem, who acted treacherously against Abimelech.

In this story God brings deliverance for Israel not by his Spirit coming upon a judge (cf. 3:10) but by sending a “spirit of disaster” between Abimelek and the Shechemites (see 9:56–57). This phrase refers to the spirit as an agent of God’s judgment.

docs.title: kennethway
docs.text: An evil spirit was used by God to judge Abimelech. God is not evil, but evil powers are subject to his control (cf. 1 Sa. 16:14; Jb. 1:12).

docs.title: v.24
docs.text: God did this in order that the crime against Jerub-Baal's seventy sons, the shedding of their blood, might be avenged on their brother Abimelech and on the citizens of Shechem, who had helped him murder his brothers.

docs.title: v.25
docs.text: In opposition to him these citizens of Shechem set men on the hilltops to ambush and rob everyone who passed by, and this was reported to Abimelech.

docs.title: v.26
docs.text: Now Gaal son of Ebed moved with his brothers into Shechem, and its citizens put their confidence in him.

docs.title: v.27
docs.text: After they had gone out into the fields and gathered the grapes and trodden them, they held a festival in the temple of their god. While they were eating and drinking, they cursed Abimelech.

docs.title: v.28
docs.text: Then Gaal son of Ebed said, "Who is Abimelech, and who is Shechem, that we should be subject to him? Isn't he Jerub-Baal's son, and isn't Zebul his deputy? Serve the men of Hamor, Shechem's father! Why should we serve Abimelech?

docs.title: v.29
docs.text: If only this people were under my command! Then I would get rid of him. I would say to Abimelech, 'Call out your whole army!'"

docs.title: v.30
docs.text: When Zebul the governor of the city heard what Gaal son of Ebed said, he was very angry.

docs.title: v.31
docs.text: Under cover he sent messengers to Abimelech, saying, "Gaal son of Ebed and his brothers have come to Shechem and are stirring up the city against you.

docs.title: v.32
docs.text: Now then, during the night you and your men should come and lie in wait in the fields.

docs.title: v.33
docs.text: In the morning at sunrise, advance against the city. When Gaal and his men come out against you, do whatever your hand finds to do."

docs.title: v.34
docs.text: So Abimelech and all his troops set out by night and took up concealed positions near Shechem in four companies.

docs.title: v.35
docs.text: Now Gaal son of Ebed had gone out and was standing at the entrance to the city gate just as Abimelech and his soldiers came out from their hiding place.

docs.title: v.36
docs.text: When Gaal saw them, he said to Zebul, "Look, people are coming down from the tops of the mountains!" Zebul replied, "You mistake the shadows of the mountains for men."

docs.title: v.37
docs.text: But Gaal spoke up again: "Look, people are coming down from the center of the land, and a company is coming from the direction of the soothsayers' tree."

docs.title: v.38
docs.text: Then Zebul said to him, "Where is your big talk now, you who said, 'Who is Abimelech that we should be subject to him?' Aren't these the men you ridiculed? Go out and fight them!"

docs.title: v.39
docs.text: So Gaal led out the citizens of Shechem and fought Abimelech.

docs.title: v.40
docs.text: Abimelech chased him, and many fell wounded in the flight—all the way to the entrance to the gate.

docs.title: v.41
docs.text: Abimelech stayed in Arumah, and Zebul drove Gaal and his brothers out of Shechem.

docs.title: v.42
docs.text: The next day the people of Shechem went out to the fields, and this was reported to Abimelech.

docs.title: v.43
docs.text: So he took his men, divided them into three companies and set an ambush in the fields. When he saw the people coming out of the city, he rose to attack them.

docs.title: v.44
docs.text: Abimelech and the companies with him rushed forward to a position at the entrance to the city gate. Then two companies rushed upon those in the fields and struck them down.

docs.title: v.45
docs.text: All that day Abimelech pressed his attack against the city until he had captured it and killed its people. Then he destroyed the city and scattered salt over it.

docs.title: v.46
docs.text: On hearing this, the citizens in the tower of Shechem went into the stronghold of the temple of El-Berith.

docs.title: v.47
docs.text: When Abimelech heard that they had assembled there,

docs.title: v.48
docs.text: he and all his men went up Mount Zalmon. He took an ax and cut off some branches, which he lifted to his shoulders. He ordered the men with him, "Quick! Do what you have seen me do!"

docs.title: v.49
docs.text: So all the men cut branches and followed Abimelech. They piled them against the stronghold and set it on fire over the people inside. So all the people in the tower of Shechem, about a thousand men and women, also died.

docs.title: v.50
docs.text: Next Abimelech went to Thebez and besieged it and captured it.

docs.title: v.51
docs.text: Inside the city, however, was a strong tower, to which all the men and women—all the people of the city—fled. They locked themselves in and climbed up on the tower roof.

docs.title: v.52

docs.title: Overview:
docs.text:
Theme: The Book of Mourning Key Scripture: 3:22-23

Chapter 1: The First Poem - Anguish of Jersusalem's Desolation Chapter 2: The Second Poem - Anguish for Jerusalem Destroyed in God's Wrath Chapter 3: The Thrid Poem - Jeremiah's Grief and Hope Chapter 4: The Fourth Poem - The Horror of the Siege Chapter 5: The Fifth Poem - Prayer for Restoration

Purposes: 1. To express through the prophet in a series of lamentations the sorrow of the heart of God over Jerusalem 2. To record the affliction and desolation of Jerusalem

Messages: 1. The sin of disobedience to God's Laws brings desolation and the wrath of God. 2. Though God loves His own people and has compassion for His people, He must yet punish the willfully obstinate and disobedient.

docs.title: v.2
docs.text:
Bitterly she weeps at night,     tears are on her cheeks. Among all her lovers     there is no one to comfort her. All her friends have betrayed her;     they have become her enemies.

In the "night" of her desolation, Jerusalem is pictured as weeping, not merely because of her sufferings, but even more because she had been betrayed by her "lovers" and "friends." These terms (cf. Jer 4:30; 30:14) are best explained by Ezek 23 and Hos 8:9-10. The suggestions is that once the monarchy was firmly established, Israel was always faced with an inescapable choice. She could rely on God for her safety against external aggression, or she could turn to allies great and small (cf. Hos 5:13, 8:8, 11; 14:3), but both the northern and the southern leaders would not listen. Judah had learned that such friends were a broken reed (Ezek 29:6-7).

docs.title: ellison
docs.text: Jeremiah’s sorrow is deep and plain; even though Jerusalem’s conquest vindicated Jeremiah’s many prophecies, he has no sense of triumph or “I told you so.” Jeremiah deeply sorrows with the sorrow of Jerusalem and Judah.

docs.title: v.8
docs.text:
Jerusalem has sinned greatly     and so has become unclean. All who honored her despise her,     for they have all seen her naked; she herself groans     and turns away.

Jerusalem is compared to a debased prostitute, shamelessly exposing her nakedness and indifferent to the marks of menstrual blood on her garments. Since prostitution repeatedly used for Israel's idolatry and Baal worship, it is obviously implied here. The completeness of Israel's collapse has finally brought her to her senses. She knows she has no grounds for begging for a reversal of fortune, but the insolent triumphing of the enemy calls for divine retribution (cf. Isa 10:12). "The enemy has triumphed" is literally correct but misleading. It is not the victory but the insolent boasting after it that is meant.

docs.title: v.15
docs.text:
“The Lord has rejected     all the warriors in my midst; he has summoned an army against me     to crush my young men. In his winepress the Lord has trampled     Virgin Daughter Judah.

So bitter is the experience that Jerusalem does not use the name "Lord" (yahweh), with its covenant associations (cf. Ex 3:14), but "Lord" (adonay). Thus the poet is saying: "The Lord has rejected all the warriors in my midst," treating them like chaff: "he has summoned [a festival] against me to crush my young men," not merely to thresh them; and "in his winepress the Lord has trampled the Virgin Daughter of Judah," to provide the wine of rejoiccing.

docs.title: v.16
docs.text:
“This is why I weep     and my eyes overflow with tears. No one is near to comfort me,     no one to restore my spirit. My children are destitute     because the enemy has prevailed.”

Jerusalem's heartbroken sob is that "the enemy has prevailed." Defeat is bitter, but doubly so when the victors are God's enemies.

docs.title: v.2
docs.text:
Without pity the Lord has swallowed up all the dwellings of Jacob; in his wrath he has torn down the strongholds of the Daughter of Judah. He has brought her kingdom and its princes down to the ground in dishonor.

The Lord's judgements are just and righteous. Why would the Lord pity the execution of his true justice?

docs.title: v.11
docs.text:
My eyes fail from weeping, I am in torment within, my heart is poured out on the ground because my people are destroyed, because children and infants faint in the streets of the city.

Jeremiah let the situation cut him.

docs.title: v.14
docs.text:
The visions of your prophets were false and worthless; they did not expose your sin to ward off your captivity. The oracles they gave you were false and misleading.

The prophetic spirit exposes sin since it is the testimony of Jesus, the Lamb who takes away every sin.

docs.title: jj
docs.text: The best commentaries on this verse are Jer 23:18-22 and Ezek 13:10-16. Just as many preachers are so obsessed with the holiness of the church that they have not been able to take its shortcomings seriously, so it was in Israel. It took the shock of the Babylonian exile to break the power and influence of the popular prophets and to discredit them finally.

docs.title: v.15
docs.text:
All who pass your way clap their hands at you; they scoff and shake their heads at the Daughter of Jerusalem: "Is this the city that was called the perfection of beauty, the joy of the whole earth?"

Even the pagans know the standard to which God has called Jerusalem to be.

docs.title: v.18
docs.text: The hearts of the people cry out to the Lord. O wall of the Daughter of Zion, let your tears flow like a river day and night; give yourself no relief, your eyes no rest.

docs.text: Arise, cry out in the night, as the watches of the night begin; pour out your heart like water in the presence of the Lord. Lift up your hands to him for the lives of your children, who faint from hunger at the head of every street.

docs.text:
He has broken my teeth with gravel; he has trampled me in the dust.

What a figure to express disgust, pain, and the consequent incapacity of taking food for the support of life; a man, instead of bread, being obliged to eat small pebbles till all his teeth are broken to pieces by endeavouring to grind them. One can scarcely read this description without feeling the toothache.

God also remembers our wanderings. See Psalm56#v 8.

docs.title: v.20-21

I well remember them, and my soul is downcast within me. 21Yet this I call to mind and therefore I have hope:

It is evident that in the preceding verses there is a bitterness of complaint against the bitterness of adversity, that is not becoming to man when under the chastising hand of God; and, while indulging this feeling, all hope fled. Here we find a different feeling; he humbles himself under the mighty hand of God, and then his hope revives.

docs.title: clarke
docs.text: At the south of Africa the sea was generally so stormy, when the frail barks of the Portuguese went sailing south, that they named it the Cape of Storms; but after that cape had been well rounded by bolder navigators, they named it the Cape of Good Hope. In your experience you had many a Cape of Storms, but you have weathered them all, and now, let them be a Cape of Good Hope to you.

docs.title: v.22

Because of the LORD's great love we are not consumed, for his compassions never fail.

See where Jeremiah gets his comfort; he seems to say, ‘Bad as my case is, it might have been worse, for I might have been consumed, and I should have been consumed if the Lord’s compassions had failed.’

docs.title: v.23
docs.text:
They are new every morning; great is your faithfulness.

Each dawning day gives mankind hope in fresh mercies and compassions from God. We need a constant supply and God has promised to send them without fail. No matter how bad the past day was, God’s people can look to the new morning with faith and hope.

docs.title: enduringword
docs.text: Our treasures, which we lay up on earth, are the stagnant pools; but the treasure which God gives us from heaven, in providence and in grace, is the crystal fount which wells up from the eternal deeps, and is always fresh and always new.

docs.title: v.24
